revision.comment: Remove off topic Super Hornet procurement text. Not really relevant to F-35, but the CF-18 replacement competition might be though.
revision.text:
{{Redirect|F-35|other uses|F35 (disambiguation){{!}}F35 (disambiguation)}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {|{{Infobox aircraft begin |name= F-35 Lightning II |image=File:F-35A flight (cropped).jpg |caption= F-35A Lightning II |alt=Gray fighter aircraft flying against a backdrop of clouds. }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type= [[Stealth aircraft|Stealth]] [[multirole combat aircraft|multirole fighter]] |national origin= United States |manufacturer= [[Lockheed Martin Aeronautics]] |first flight= 15 December 2006 |introduction= F-35B: 31 July 2015 ([[United States Marine Corps|USMC]]){{cite news |url=http://www.marines.mil/News/NewsDisplay/tabid/3258/Article/611657/us-marines-corps-declares-the-f-35b-operational.aspx |title=U.S. Marines Corps declares the F-35B operational |last1=Story |first1=Courtesy |date=31 July 2015 |website=www.marines.mil |publisher=Headquarters Marine Corps |accessdate=31 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marines-stick-to-f-35b-dates-despite-new-problems-410518/|title=US Marines stick to F-35B dates despite new problems|author=Reed Business Information Limited|work=flightglobal.com|accessdate=25 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/article/50173/f-35b-on-track-for-operational-readiness-despite-software-challenges |title=F-35B on track for operational readiness despite software challenges |work=janes.com |accessdate=25 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429094814/http://www.janes.com/article/50173/f-35b-on-track-for-operational-readiness-despite-software-challenges |archivedate=29 April 2015 |df=dmy }}
F-35A: 2 August 2016 ([[United States Air Force|USAF]]){{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/07/us-lockheed-martin-fighter-airforce-idUSKBN0MY26Q20150407|title=U.S. Air Force eyes future F-35 engine and arms upgrades|work=Reuters|accessdate=25 May 2015|date=7 April 2015}}
F-35C: 2018 ([[United States Navy|USN]]){{cite web |url=http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2014/09/the-current-status-of-the-f-35-in-three-charts/|title=The Current Status of the F-35, in Three Charts|work=Intercepts – Defense News}} |status= In service |primary user= [[United States Air Force]] |more users= [[United States Marine Corps]]
[[United States Navy]]
[[Royal Air Force]] |produced= 2006–present |number built= 180+ as of November 2016{{cite web|url=https://www.f35.com/about/fast-facts|title=F-35 Fast Facts - F-35 Lightning II|work=f35.com|accessdate=24 November 2016}} |program cost= [[US$]]1.508 trillion (through 2070 in then-year dollars), US$55.1B for RDT&E, $319.1B for procurement, $4.8B for MILCON, $1123.8B for operations & sustainment (2015 estimate)http://www.jsf.mil/news/docs/20160324_Fact-Sheet.pdf |unit cost= F-35A: $98M ([[low rate initial production]] without engine, full production in 2018 to be $85M){{cite web|url=https://www.f35.com/about/fast-facts/cost|title=About: Fast Facts: Cost – F-35 Lightning II|work=F-35 Lightning II|accessdate=31 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/f-35-deal-targets-unit-cost-below-100-million|title=F-35 Deal Targets Unit Cost Below $100 Million|publisher=}}
F-35B: US$104M (low rate initial production without engine)
F-35C: US$116M (low rate initial production without engine) |developed from= [[Lockheed Martin X-35]] |variants with their own articles= |developed into= }} |} The '''Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II''' is a family of single-seat, single-engine, all-weather [[Stealth aircraft|stealth]] [[Multirole combat aircraft|multirole fighters]] undergoing final development and testing for the United States and partner nations. The [[Fifth-generation jet fighter|fifth generation]] combat aircraft is designed to perform [[attack aircraft|ground attack]] and [[aerial warfare|air defense]] missions. The F-35 has three main models: the F-35A [[CTOL|conventional takeoff and landing]] (CTOL) variant, the F-35B [[STOVL|short take-off and vertical-landing]] (STOVL) variant, and the F-35C carrier-based [[CATOBAR|Catapult Assisted Take-Off But Arrested Recovery]] (CATOBAR) variant. On 31 July 2015, the first squadron of F-35B fighters was declared ready for deployment after intensive testing by the United States Marines.{{cite news| url=http://time.com/3980838/marines-f-35-fighter-jet/ |work=Time |first=Dan |last=Kedmey |title=New F-35 Fighter Jets Are Ready for Combat |date=31 July 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/marines-say-costly-f-35-jet-fighter-is-finally-ready-1438367615 |work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Doug |last=Cameron |title=Marines Say Costly F-35 Jet Fighter Is Finally Ready |date=31 July 2015}} On 2 August 2016, the U.S. Air Force declared its first squadron of F-35A fighters as combat-ready.{{cite news |url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/story/breaking-news/2016/08/02/f35-ioc-air-force-operational-acc-combat/87948142/ |work=AirForceTimes |first=Valerie |last=Insinna |title=Air Force Declares F-35A Ready for Combat |date=2 August 2016}} {{dead link|date=September 2016}} The F-35 is descended from the [[Lockheed Martin X-35|X-35]], which was the winning design of the [[Joint Strike Fighter program|Joint Strike Fighter]] (JSF) program. It is being designed and built by an aerospace industry team led by [[Lockheed Martin]]. Other major F-35 industry partners include [[Northrop Grumman]], [[Pratt & Whitney]] and [[BAE Systems]]. The F-35 took its first flight on 15 December 2006. The United States plans to buy 2,457 aircraft. The F-35 variants are intended to provide the bulk of the manned tactical airpower of the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]], [[United States Navy|Navy]] and the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] over the coming decades. Deliveries of the F-35 for the U.S. military are scheduled to be completed in 2037{{cite web|url=http://www.military.com/daily-news/2013/12/17/air-force-seeks-jets-beyond-c17-and-even-jsf.html |title=Air Force Seeks Jets Beyond C-17 and Even JSF |work=military.com |date=17 December 2013 |publisher=Military Advantage |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Kris |last=Osborn |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525005157/http://www.military.com/daily-news/2013/12/17/air-force-seeks-jets-beyond-c17-and-even-jsf.html |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} with a projected service life up to 2070.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-f-35-service-life-extended-to-2070-423536/ Lockheed F-35 service life extended to 2070] – Flightglobal.com, 25 March 2016 F-35 JSF development is being principally funded by the United States with additional funding from partners. The partner nations are either [[NATO]] members or close U.S. allies. The United Kingdom, Italy, Australia, Canada, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, and Turkey are part of the active development program;[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/products/f35/global-partnerships.html "F-35 Global Partnerships."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902025203/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/products/f35/global-partnerships.html |date=2 September 2012 }} Lockheed Martin. Retrieved: 31 October 2012.Dudley, Richard. [http://defense-update.com/20120305_program-partners-confirm-support-for-f-35-joint-strike-fighter.html "Program Partners Confirm Support for F-35 Joint Strike Fighter"]. ''Defence Update'', 5 March 2012. Retrieved: 18 March 2012. [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II procurement|several additional countries]] have ordered, or are considering ordering, the F-35. The program is the most expensive military weapons system in history, and it has been the object of much criticism from those inside and outside government—in the US and in allied countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2013/09/joint-strike-fighter-lockheed-martin|title=Will the F-35, the U.S. Military’s Flaw-Filled, Years-Overdue Joint Strike Fighter, Ever Actually Fly?|author=Adam Ciralsky|work=Vanity Fair|accessdate=29 September 2015}} Critics argue that the plane is "plagued with design flaws," with many blaming the procurement process in which Lockheed was allowed "to design, test, and produce the F-35 all at the same time, instead of ... [identifying and fixing] defects before firing up its production line." By 2014, the program was "$163 billion over budget [and] seven years behind schedule."{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/f-35-fighter-plane-costs-103579|title=Fighter plane cost overruns detailed|work=POLITICO|accessdate=29 September 2015}} Critics further contend that the program's high [[sunk costs]] and political momentum make it "too big to kill."{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-22/flawed-f-35-fighter-too-big-to-kill-as-lockheed-hooks-45-states|title=Flawed F-35 Too Big to Kill as Lockheed Hooks 45 States|date=22 February 2013|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=29 September 2015}} ==Development== ===JSF program requirements and selection=== {{Main article|Joint Strike Fighter program}} The JSF program was designed to replace the United States military [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]], [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10]], [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18]] (excluding newer [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|E/F "Super Hornet"]] variants) and [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B]] tactical fighter and attack aircraft. To keep development, production, and operating costs down, a common design was planned in three variants that share 80 percent of their parts:{{update after|2015|4|4}} * [[#F-35A|F-35A]], conventional take off and landing ([[CTOL]]) variant. * [[#F-35B|F-35B]], short-take off and vertical-landing ([[STOVL]]) variant. * [[#F-35C|F-35C]], carrier-based [[CATOBAR]] (CV) variant. [[File:F-35 Wind Tunnel Model.jpg|thumb|An F-35 wind tunnel testing model in the [[Arnold Engineering Development Center]]'s 16-foot transonic [[wind tunnel]]|alt=Engineer handling a metallic scale model of jet fighter in wind-tunnel]] George Standridge, Vice President of Strategy and Business Development for Lockheed Martin Aeronautics, predicted in 2006 that the F-35 would be four times more effective than legacy fighters in air-to-air combat, eight times more effective in air-to-ground combat, and three times more effective in reconnaissance and [[Suppression of Enemy Air Defenses]] – while having better range and requiring less logistics support and having around the same procurement costs (if development costs are ignored) as legacy fighters.[http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Lockheed_Martin_F22_and_F35_5th_Gen_Revolution_In_Military_Aviation.html "Lockheed Martin F22 and F35 5th Gen Revolution In Military Aviation."] ''Space Daily'', 22 February 2006. The design goals call for the F-35 to be the premier strike aircraft through 2040 and to be second only to the [[Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor|F-22 Raptor]] in [[air supremacy]].[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35.htm "F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Lightning II."] ''Global Security''. Retrieved: 7 April 2010. The JSF development contract was signed on 16 November 1996, and the contract for System Development and Demonstration (SDD) was awarded on 26 October 2001 to Lockheed Martin, whose [[Lockheed Martin X-35|X-35]] beat the [[Boeing X-32]]. Although both aircraft met or exceeded requirements, the X-35 design was considered to have less risk and more growth potential.Keijsper 2007, p. 119. The designation of the new fighter as "F-35" is out-of-sequence with standard [[United States Department of Defense|DoD]] aircraft numbering,Polmar 2005, p. 398. by which it should have been "F-24". It came as a surprise even to the company, which had been referring to the aircraft in-house by this expected designation.Parsch, Andreas. [http://www.designation-systems.net/usmilav/nonstandard-mds.html#_MDS_F35 "Designation Systems."] ''Designation Systems'', 27 April 2006. Retrieved 23 November 2009. The development of the F-35 is unusual for a fighter aircraft in that no two-seat trainer versions have been built for any of the variants; advanced flight simulators mean that no trainer versions were deemed necessary.Thompson, Mark. "The Most Expensive Weapon Ever Built." ''Time'' magazine, 25 February 2013, pp. 26–30 (lack of 2-seat trainer variants cited on p. 27). Instead F-16s have been used as bridge trainers between the T-38 and the F-35. The [[T-X program|T-X]] was intended to be used to train future F-35 pilots, but this might succumb to budget pressures in the USAF.{{cite web |last= Orlando |first= Dave |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-may-not-be-able-to-afford-t-x-jet-trainer-project-382628/ |title= USAF may not be able to afford T-X jet trainer project |website= Flightglobal |date= 22 February 2013 |accessdate= 24 February 2013 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130227063720/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-may-not-be-able-to-afford-t-x-jet-trainer-project-382628/ |archivedate= 27 February 2013}} ===Design phase=== Based on wind tunnel testing, Lockheed Martin slightly enlarged its X-35 design into the F-35. The forward fuselage is {{convert|5|in|mm|sigfig=2}} longer to make room for avionics. Correspondingly, the horizontal [[stabilator]]s were moved {{convert|2|in|mm|sigfig=2}} rearward to retain balance and control. The top surface of the fuselage was raised by {{convert|1|in|mm|sigfig=2}} along the center line. Also, it was decided to increase the size of the F-35B STOVL variant's weapons bay to be common with the other two variants. Manufacturing of parts for the first F-35 prototype [[airframe]] began in November 2003.Keijsper 2007, pp. 122, 124. Because the X-35 did not have weapons bays, their addition in the F-35 would cause design changes which would lead to later weight problems.{{cite web |url= http://www.codeonemagazine.com/f35_article.html?item_id=28 |website= Code One Magazine |publisher= Lockheed Martin |title= X to F: F-35 Lightning II And Its X-35 Predecessors |first= Eric |last= Hehs |date= 15 May 2008 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/outgoing-f-35-programme-boss-shares-hard-won-lessons-383932/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020012508/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/outgoing-f-35-programme-boss-shares-hard-won-lessons-383932/|title=Outgoing F-35 programme boss shares hard won lessons|archivedate=20 October 2013|work=flightglobal.com|accessdate=2 February 2015}} The F-35B STOVL variant was in danger of missing performance requirements in 2004 because it weighed too much; reportedly, by {{convert|2200|lb|kg|abbr=on}} or 8 percent. In response, Lockheed Martin added engine thrust and thinned airframe members; reduced the size of the common weapons bay and vertical stabilizers; re-routed some thrust from the roll-post outlets to the main nozzle; and redesigned the wing-mate joint, portions of the electrical system, and the portion of the aircraft immediately behind the cockpit.Fulghum, David A. and Robert Wall. "USAF Plans for Fighters Change." ''Aviation Week and Space Technology'', 19 September 2004. Many of the changes were applied to all three variants to maintain high levels of commonality. By September 2004, the weight reduction effort had reduced the aircraft's design weight by {{convert|2700|lb|kg|sigfig=2}},Keijsper 2007, p. 124, but the redesign cost $6.2 billion and delayed the project by 18 months.{{cite web |url=http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/weight-watchers-13117183/?all |title=Weight Watchers: How a team of engineers and a crash diet saved the Joint Strike Fighter |work=Air & Space Magazine |date=November 2006 |accessdate=1 April 2013 |first=Joe |last=Pappalardo |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.airspacemag.com%2Fmilitary-aviation%2Fweight-watchers-13117183%2F%3Fall&date=2014-05-24 |archivedate=24 May 2014 |deadurl=no}} On 7 July 2006, the U.S. Air Force, the lead service for the aircraft, officially announced the name of the F-35: ''Lightning II'', in honor of Lockheed's World War II-era twin-propeller [[Lockheed P-38 Lightning]] for the [[United States Army Air Forces]] and the Cold War-era jet, the [[English Electric Lightning]] for the [[Royal Air Force]].[http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/130499/lightning-ii-moniker-given-to-joint-strike-fighter.aspx "'Lightning II' moniker given to Joint Strike Fighter."] ''Air Force Link'', United States Air Force, 7 June 2006. Retrieved 1 December 2008.{{refn|Quote: "The F-35 Lightning II will carry on the legacy of two of the greatest and most capable fighter aircraft of all time. Just as the P-38 and the British Lightning were at the top of their class during their day, the F-35 will redefine multi-role fighter capability in the 21st century." Ralph D. Heath, president of Lockheed Martin Aeronautics Co.{{cite web |last1= Kent |first1= John R. |first2= John |last2= Smith |url= http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2006/july/LOCKHEEDMARTINJOINTSTRIKEFIGHTEROFF.html |title= F-35 Joint Strike Fighter was officially named Lightning II. |website= Lockheed Martin |date= 7 July 2006 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130103183520/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2006/july/LOCKHEEDMARTINJOINTSTRIKEFIGHTEROFF.html |archivedate= 3 January 2013}} [http://www.jsf.mil/downloads/documents/JSF_F-35_2006_Inauguration%20Press%20Release.doc (DOC) via jsf.mil]|group=N}} [[Lockheed Martin Aeronautics]] is the prime contractor and performs aircraft final assembly, overall system integration, mission system, and provides forward fuselage, wings and [[aircraft flight control system]]. [[Northrop Grumman]] provides [[active electronically scanned array]] (AESA) radar, electro-optical [[AN/AAQ-37]] Distributed Aperture System (DAS), Communications, Navigation, Identification (CNI), center fuselage, weapons bay, and [[tailhook|arrestor gear]]. [[BAE Systems]] provides the Flight Control Software (FCS1), the [[electronic warfare]] systems, crew life support and escape systems, aft fuselage, empennages as well as the horizontal and vertical tails. [[Alenia Aeronautica|Alenia]] will perform final assembly for Italy and, according to an Alenia executive, assembly of all European aircraft with the exception of Turkey and the United Kingdom."Italy Wins JSF Final Assembly: U.K. Presses Maintenance, Support." ''Aviation Week'', February 2013. The F-35 program has seen a great deal of investment in automated production facilities. For example, Handling Specialty produced the wing assembly platforms for Lockheed Martin.[http://www.handling.com/TurnKeyCapabilities.aspx "Handling Specialty Turn Key Capabilities."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311001554/http://www.handling.com/TurnKeyCapabilities.aspx |date=11 March 2012 }} handling.com. Retrieved: 16 November 2010. [[File:A U.S. Air Force pilot navigates an F-35A Lightning II aircraft assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron, 33rd Fighter Wing into position to refuel with a KC-135 Stratotanker assigned to the 336th Air Refueling 130516-F-XL333-505.jpg|thumb|F-35A moving into position to refuel.]] On 19 December 2008, Lockheed Martin rolled out the first weight-optimized F-35A, designated AF-1. It was the first F-35 built at full production speed, and is structurally identical to the production F-35As that were delivered starting in 2010.{{cite web |last1= Kent |first1= John R. |first2= Joseph W. |last2= Stout |url= http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2008/december/Weight-OptimizedF-35TestF.html |title= Weight-Optimized F-35 Test Fleet Adds Conventional Take off And Landing Variant. |website= Lockheed Martin |date= 23 December 2008 |accessdate= 23 November 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130103153548/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2008/december/Weight-OptimizedF-35TestF.html |archivedate= 3 January 2013 }} On 5 January 2009, six F-35s had been built, including AF-1; another 13 pre-production test aircraft and four production aircraft were being manufactured.Moore, Mona. "F-35 production on target." ''Northwest Florida Daily News'', 5 January 2009, Volume 62, Number 341, p. A1. On 6 April 2009, U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Robert Gates]] proposed speeding up production for the U.S. to buy 2,443 F-35s.Gearan, Anne. [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/politics/2008993406_apdefensebudget.html "Defense Secretary Gates proposes weapons cuts."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524210516/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/politics/2008993406_apdefensebudget.html |date=24 May 2009 }} ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', 7 April 2009. ===Program cost overruns and delays=== {{Undue weight section|date=May 2015}} The F-35 program has experienced a number of cost overruns and developmental delays. The program's delays have come under fire from the [[U.S. Congress]] and some [[U.S. Department of Defense]] officials. The program has undergone a number of reassessments and changes since 2006. The [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) warned in March 2006 that excessive concurrency ("an overlap of flight testing and initial production"{{cite web|url = https://www.f35.com/about/fast-facts/cost|title = Producing, Operating and Supporting a 5th Generation Fighter|date = |accessdate = November 8, 2015|website = F-35 Lightning II|publisher = Lockheed Martin}}) might result in expensive refits for several hundred F-35 aircraft that are planned for production before design testing is completed.[http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06356.pdf GAO-06-356, "DOD Plans to Enter Production before Testing Demonstrates Acceptable Performance."] ''GAO'', March 2006. In 2010, acquisition chief Ashton Carter issued an Acquisition Decision Memorandum restructuring the F-35 program.[http://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc31394/m1/1/high_res_d/RL30563_2010Nov10.pdf untitled] In November 2010, the GAO found that "Managing an extensive, still-maturing global network of suppliers adds another layer of complexity to producing aircraft efficiently and on-time" and that "due to the extensive amount of testing still to be completed, the program could be required to make alterations to its production processes, changes to its supplier base, and costly retrofits to produced and fielded aircraft, if problems are discovered."[http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-11-233SP?source=ra GAO-11-233SP, "Defense Acquisitions: Assessments of Selected Weapon Programs."] ''Gao.gov,'' 29 August 2008. Retrieved 4 December 2011. USAF budget data in 2010, along with other sources, projected the F-35 to have a [[flyaway cost]] from US$89 million to US$200 million over the planned production run.[http://www.saffm.hq.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-100128-072.pdf "FY 2011 Budget Estimates."] ''U.S. Air Force'', February 2010, pp. 1–47.{{cite news|last=McPhedran|first=Ian|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/stealth-fighters-cheap-at-140m/story-e6frf7l6-1225909569574|title=Stealth fighters cheap at $140m.|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=25 August 2010|access-date=21 October 2010}} In February 2011, the Pentagon put a price of $207.6 million on each of the 32 aircraft to be acquired in FY2012, rising to $304.16 million (a total acquisition cost of $9.7 billion for 32 aircraft) if its share of research, development, test and evaluation (RDT&E) spending is included.{{cite web |url=http://www.defense-aerospace.com/articles-view/reports/2/122979/us-acquisition-costs-by-weapon-system.html |title=U.S. Program Acquisition Costs by Weapon System |work=defense-aerospace.com |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420024939/http://www.defense-aerospace.com/articles-view/reports/2/122979/us-acquisition-costs-by-weapon-system.html |archivedate=20 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |author1=}}{{cite web |url=http://comptroller.defense.gov/defbudget/fy2012/FY2012_Weapons.pdf |title=Program Acquisition Costs By Weapon System |work=comptroller.defense.gov |date=February 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121002254/http://comptroller.defense.gov/defbudget/fy2012/FY2012_Weapons.pdf |archivedate=21 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |author1=Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) / CFO}} On 21 April 2009, media reports, citing Pentagon sources, said that during 2007 and 2008, spies downloaded several terabytes of data related to the F-35's design and electronics systems, potentially compromising the aircraft and aiding the development of defense systems against it.Gorman, Siobhan. [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB124027491029837401.html "Computer Spies Breach Fighter-Jet Project."] ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 21 April 2009. Retrieved 29 March 2010. Lockheed Martin rejected suggestions that the project was compromised, stating it "does not believe any classified information had been stolen".Cullen, Simon. [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/22/2549705.htm "Jet maker denies F-35 security breach."] [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], 22 April 2009. Retrieved 29 March 2010. Other sources suggested that the incident caused both hardware and software redesigns to be more resistant to cyber attack.{{cite journal |title= China's Role In JSF's Spiraling Costs |journal= Aviation Week |first1= David |last1= Fulghum |first2= Bill |last2= Sweetman |first3= Amy |last3= Butler |date= 8 February 2012 }} In March 2012, [[BAE Systems]] was reported to be the target of cyber espionage. BAE Systems refused to comment on the report, although they did state, "[Our] own cyber security capability can detect, prevent and rectify such attacks."{{cite web|url=http://www.strategicdefenceintelligence.com/article/IV9DSTecarI/2012/03/12/comment_bae_systems_hacked_by_chinese_spies |title=BAE Systems 'hacked by Chinese spies |website=Strategic Defense Intelligence |first=Berenice |last=Baker |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=18 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301010024/https://www.strategicdefenceintelligence.com/article/IV9DSTecarI/2012/03/12/comment_bae_systems_hacked_by_chinese_spies |archivedate=1 March 2014 |df=dmy }} On 9 November 2009, Ashton Carter, under-secretary of defense for acquisition, technology and logistics, acknowledged that the Pentagon "joint estimate team" (JET) had found possible future cost and schedule overruns in the project and that he would be holding meetings to attempt to avoid these.Bennett, John T. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4367942&c=AME&s=AIR "Plan Afoot to Halt F-35 Cost Hikes, Delays."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} defensenews.com, 9 November 2009. Retrieved 23 November 2009. On 1 February 2010, Gates removed the JSF Program Manager, U.S. Marine Corps Major General David Heinz, and withheld $614 million in payments to Lockheed Martin because of program costs and delays.Clark, Colin. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/02/01/gates-fires-jsf-program-manager/ "Gates Fires JSF Program Manager."] dodbuzz.com, 1 February 2010. Retrieved 21 March 2010.{{cite news |url= http://blogs.star-telegram.com/files/gates-criticizes-lockheed-over-f-35-2-02-10.pdf |title= Gates Criticizes F-35 Progress, Fires Top Officer |newspaper= Star-Telegram |location= Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas |first= Bob |last= Cox |date= 2 February 2010 |accessdate= 24 June 2011}} On 11 March 2010, a report from the [[Government Accountability Office]] to [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services]] projected the overall unit cost of an F-35A to be $113 million in "today's money."[http://australianaviation.com.au/jsf-faces-us-senate-grilling/ "JSF faces US Senate grilling."] australianaviation.com.au, 12 March 2010. In 2010, Pentagon officials disclosed that the F-35 program had exceeded its original cost estimates by more than 50 percent.Shalal-Esa, Andrea and Tim Dobbyn, ed. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/03/12/lockheed-fighter-idUSN1123180820100312 "Price of F35 fighter soars."] Reuters. Retrieved: 12 September 2011. An internal Pentagon report critical of the JSF project stated that "affordability is no longer embraced as a core pillar". In 2010, Lockheed Martin expected they would be able to reduce costs projected by government estimators by 20 percent.{{cite news |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/06/01/lockheed-fighter-idUSN0111242120100601?type=marketsNews |title= Lockheed F-35 to beat Pentagon estimate by 20 pct |website= Reuters |first= Andrea |last= Shalal-Esa |date= 1 June 2010 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }} On 24 March 2010, Robert Gates, Secretary of Defense, in testimony before Congress, declared the cost overruns and delays "unacceptable," characterizing previous cost and schedule estimates as "overly rosy". Gates insisted the F-35 would become "the backbone of U.S. air combat for the next generation" and informed Congress that he had extended the development period by an additional 13 months and budgeted $3 billion more for the testing program, while slowing down production.Thompson, Mark. [http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1975139,00.html "The Costly F-35: The Saga of America's Next Fighter Jet."] ''Time'', 25 March 2010. In August 2010, Lockheed Martin announced delays in resolving a "wing-at-mate overlap" production problem, which would slow initial production.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/08/16/346077/fix-for-f-35-final-assembly-problem-pushed-back.html "Fix for F-35 final assembly problem pushed back."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818233320/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/08/16/346077/fix-for-f-35-final-assembly-problem-pushed-back.html |date=18 August 2010 }} ''Flight International'', 16 August 2010. Retrieved: 24 August 2010. In November 2010, as part of a cost-cutting measure, the co-chairs of the [[National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform]] suggested cancelling the F-35B and halving orders for F-35As and F-35Cs.Clark, Colin. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/11/10/prez-panel-wants-100b-dod-cut/ "Prez Panel Wants $100B DoD Cut; Freeze Pay, Kill F-35B, EFV."] ''DoDBuzz'', 10 November 2010.[http://www.fiscalcommission.gov/sites/fiscalcommission.gov/files/documents/Illustrative_List_11.10.2010.pdf $200 billion in illustrative savings] point 47 ''[[National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform]]'', 10 November 2010.[http://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2010/11/10/us/politics/politics-us-usa-deficit-commission-arms.html "Lockheed F–35 Fighter In Deficit Panel's Sights."] ''The New York Times'', 10 November 2010. ''[[Air Force Magazine]]'' reported that "Pentagon officials" were considering canceling the F-35B because its short range meant that the forward bases or amphibious ships from which it would operate would be in range of hostile tactical ballistic missiles.Tirpak, John A. [http://www.airforce-magazine.com/Features/modernization/Pages/box111510stovl.aspx "Shorting the F-35."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202044717/http://www.airforce-magazine.com/Features/modernization/Pages/box111510stovl.aspx |date=2 December 2010 }} ''[[Air Force Association]]'', 15 November 2010. Lockheed Martin consultant Loren B. Thompson said that this ″rumor″ was a result of the usual tensions between the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, and there was no alternative other than the F-35B as a replacement for [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B Harrier II]].Thompson, Loren B. [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/rumor-of-marine-f-35-termination-talks-is-wrong?a=1&c=1171 "Rumor Of Marine F-35 Termination Talks Is Wrong."] ''[[Lexington Institute]]'', 15 November 2010. He also confirmed that there were further delays and cost increases due to technical problems with the aircraft and software, blaming most of the delays and extra costs on redundant flight tests.Thompson, Loren. [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/pentagon-factional-disputes-are-a-key-driver-of-f-35-cost-increases?a=1&c=1171 "Pentagon Factional Disputes Are A Key Driver Of F-35 Cost Increases."] Lexington Institute, 1 November 2010. In November 2010, the [[Center for Defense Information]] expected that the F-35 program would be restructured, resulting in an additional year of delay and increasing the cost by another $5 billion.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/11/03/349254/lockheeds-f-35-faces-second-restructuring-this-year.html "Lockheed's F-35 faces second restructuring this year."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106010819/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/11/03/349254/lockheeds-f-35-faces-second-restructuring-this-year.html |date=6 November 2010 }} ''[[Flight International]]'', 3 November 2010. On 5 November 2010, the Block 1 software flew for the first time on BF-4.[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2010/november/LockheedMartinF-35BeginsF.html "Lockheed Martin F-35 Begins Flying Block 1 Software."] ''[[Lockheed Martin]]'', 15 November 2010. As of the end of 2010, it was said that only 15% of the software remained to be written, but this was reported to include the most difficult sections such as [[data fusion]].Hoyle, Craig. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/12/14/350787/can-lockheed-deliver-on-the-joint-strike-fighter-dream.html "Can Lockheed deliver on the Joint Strike Fighter dream? "] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113191713/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/12/14/350787/can-lockheed-deliver-on-the-joint-strike-fighter-dream.html |date=13 January 2011 }} ''[[Flight International]]'', 14 December 2010. In 2011, it was revealed that actually, only 50% of the estimated eight million lines of code needed had been written and that, according to the newest schedule, it would take another six years to complete the software.Warwick, Graham and Amy Butler. "F-35 Replan Adds Time, Resources For Testing." ''Aviation Week'', 8 February 2011. By 2012, the total estimated lines of code for the entire program (onboard and offboard) had grown from the previous year's estimate of 8 million lines to 24 million lines.Charette, Robert N. [http://spectrum.ieee.org/riskfactor/aerospace/military/f35-program-continues-to-struggle-with-software "F-35 Program Continues to Struggle with Software."] ''IEEE Spectrum'', 19 September 2012. In 2011, the program head and Commander of the [[Naval Air Systems Command]], Vice Admiral David Venlet, confirmed that the concurrency (testing and production at the same time) built into the program "was a miscalculation".Whittle, Richard. [http://defense.aol.com/2011/12/01/jsf-build-and-test-was-miscalculation-production-must-slow-v/ "JSF's Build And Test Was 'Miscalculation,' Adm. Venlet Says; Production Must Slow."] ''Aol Defense'', 1 December 2011. This was said during a contract dispute, in which the Pentagon insisted that Lockheed Martin help cover the costs of applying fixes found during testing of aircraft already produced.Cox, Bob. [http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/10/26/3476421/pentagon-takes-a-harder-line-with.html "Pentagon takes a harder line with Lockheed Martin over F-35."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Star-Telegram'', 26 October 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028104156/http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/10/26/3476421/pentagon-takes-a-harder-line-with.html |date=28 October 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} Lockheed Martin objected that the cost sharing posed an uninsurable, unbounded risk that the company could not cover, and later responded that the "concurrency costs for F-35 continue to reduce".Thompson, Loren. [http://www.forbes.com/sites/lorenthompson/2011/11/01/pentagon-weapon-efficiencies-are-often-an-illusion/ "Why Pentagon Weapon 'Efficiencies' Are Often An Illusion."] ''Forbes'', 1 November 2011.Katz, Yaakov. [http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Article.aspx?id=247993 "Will Iran influence pick for next IAF commander?"] ''The Jerusalem Post'', 4 December 2011. The Senate Armed Services Committee strongly backed the Pentagon position.DiMascio, Jen. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story.jsp?id=news/asd/2011/11/18/01.xml "McCain Backs Hard-Line Pentagon F-35 Stance."] ''Aviation Week'', 18 November 2011. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} However in December 2011, Lockheed Martin accepted a cost sharing agreement.Clark, Colin. [http://defense.aol.com/2011/12/05/mccain-slams-jsf-calls-program-scandal-and-a-tragedy/ "McCain Slams JSF, Calls Program 'Scandal And A Tragedy;' Contract Talks Advance."] ''Aol Defense'', 5 December 2011. The Aerospace Industries Association warned that such changes would force them to anticipate cost overruns in the future when bidding on contracts.[http://www.brecorder.com/business-a-economy/single/672/189/1260018/ "US defence firms blast Pentagon on contract changes: companies warn of layoffs, higher costs."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310014625/http://www.brecorder.com/business-a-economy/single/672/189/1260018/ |date=10 March 2012 }} Reuters, 12 December 2011. As of 2012, problems found during flight testing were expected to continue to lead to higher levels of engineering changes through 2019.[http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-12-525T?source=ra "GAO-12-525T: Restructuring Added Resources and Reduced Risk, but Concurrency Is Still a Major Concern."] GAO. 20 March 2012. The total additional cost for concurrency in the program is around $1.3 billion.Pincus, Walter. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/slack-budgeting-at-defense/2012/06/06/gJQAog4aJV_story.html "Slack budgeting at Defense."] ''Washington Post'', 6 June 2012. By the next year the cost had grown to $1.7 billion.{{cite news|url=http://news.terra.com/exclusive-retrofits-to-add-17-billion-to-cost-of-f-35-gao-report,31e15e7272e4d310VgnCLD2000000dc6eb0aRCRD.html |title=Exclusive: Retrofits to add $1.7 billion to cost of F-35 – GAO report |work=news.terra.com |date=9 March 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |others=Foto: Lockheed Martin / Reuters |editor1-first=Martin |editor1-last=Howell |editor2-first=Xavier |editor2-last=Briand |author= |agency=Reuters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525010345/http://news.terra.com/exclusive-retrofits-to-add-17-billion-to-cost-of-f-35-gao-report,31e15e7272e4d310VgnCLD2000000dc6eb0aRCRD.html |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In January 2011, Defense Secretary Robert Gates expressed the Pentagon's frustration with the rising costs of the F-35 program when he said, "The culture of endless money that has taken hold must be replaced by a culture of restraint." Focusing his attention on the troubled F-35B, Gates ordered "a two-year probation", saying it "should be canceled" if corrections are unsuccessful.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/01/06/351600/us-military-unveils-possible-f-35b-redesign-in-sweeping-budget.html "US military unveils possible F-35B redesign in sweeping budget reforms."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110111051814/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/01/06/351600/us-military-unveils-possible-f-35b-redesign-in-sweeping-budget.html |date=11 January 2011 }} ''Flight International'', 6 January 2011. Gates had previously stated his support for the program.Gates, Robert. [http://www.defense.gov/speeches/speech.aspx?speechid=1543 "Speech to Air Force Academy."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304200652/http://www.defense.gov/speeches/speech.aspx?speechid=1543 |date=4 March 2011 }} defense.gov, 4 March 2011. Retrieved 8 March 2011. Some private analysts, such as Richard Aboulafia, of the Teal Group said that the F-35 program was becoming a money pit.Rabechault, Mathieu. "F-35 looking more like white elephant." Yahoo News, 13 January 2011. Gates' successor, Leon Panetta, ended the F-35B's probation on 20 January 2012, stating "The STOVL variant has made—I believe and all of us believe—sufficient progress."Marshall, Tyrone C. Jr. "Panetta Lifts F-35B Probation." ''Aviation Week'', 20 January 2012. In February 2011, former Pentagon manager [[Paul G. Kaminski]] said that the lack of a complete test plan would add five years to the JSF program.Fulghum, David A. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3a27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3a55590fb8-2da7-4769-9827-920983076d87&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "Repairing the F-35 Program."] ''Aviation Week'', 10 February 2011. [[Initial operating capability]] (IOC) will be determined by software development rather than by hardware production or pilot training.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6525163&c=AME&s=AIR "F-35 Tests Proceed, Revealing F/A-18-Like Performance."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 16 May 2011. {{Asof|2013|5}}, the USMC plans to have Initial Operating Capability by "mid-2015" for the F-35B, using Block 2B software, which gives basic air-to-air and air-to-ground capability. It is reported that the USAF plans to push ahead, expecting to have Initial Operating Capability with the F-35A in mid-2016, using Block 3I software, rather than waiting for the full-capability Block 3F software, which is expected to be available by mid-2017. The F-35C will not enter service with the USN until mid-2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article/PrintArticle.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_05_21_2013_p0-580874.xml&p=1&printView=true |title=U.S. Air Force To Move Forward Target Date For F-35 Use |first=Andrea |last=Shalal-Esa |date=21 May 2013 |work=Aviation Week |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027040520/https://www.aviationweek.com/Article/PrintArticle.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_05_21_2013_p0-580874.xml&p=1&printView=true |archivedate=27 October 2013 |df=dmy }} The $56.4 billion development project for the aircraft should be completed in 2018 when the Block 5 configuration is expected to be delivered, several years late and considerably over budget.[http://blogs.star-telegram.com/files/gao-testimony-report-03-15-11.pdf "Program Restructuring Should Improve Outcomes, but Progress Is Still Lagging Overall."] star-telegram.com, 15 March 2011. Delays in the F-35 program may lead to a "fighter gap" with the United States and other countries lacking sufficient fighter aircraft to meet their requirements.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/04/06/340121/usaf-rules-out-new-f-15s-and-f-16s-to-narrow-fighter.html "USAF rules out new F-15s and F-16s to narrow ‘fighter gap’."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812015035/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/04/06/340121/usaf-rules-out-new-f-15s-and-f-16s-to-narrow-fighter.html |date=12 August 2011 }} ''Flight International'', 4 June 2010. Israel may seek to buy second-hand [[McDonnell Douglas F-15E Strike Eagle|F-15Es]],[http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2011/04/18/Israel-eyes-used-F-15s-to-fill-for-F-35s/UPI-68101303141863/ "Israel eyes used F-15s to fill for F-35s."] United Press International, 18 April 2011. while Australia has considered buying additional [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|F/A-18 Super Hornets]] in the face of F-35 delays.[http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14701:australia-may-buy-more-super-hornets-amid-f-35-delays-report&catid=35:Aerospace&Itemid=107 "Australia may buy more Super Hornets amid F-35 delays: report."] Reuters, 13 May 2011. In May 2011, the Pentagon's top weapons buyer, Ashton Carter, said that the latest price estimate of $133 million per aircraft was not affordable.[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-19/lockheed-addressing-development-risks-of-f-35-congress-told.html "Lockheed Addressing F-35 ‘Development Risks,’ Congress Told."] ''Bloomberg News'', 19 May 2011. In 2011, ''[[The Economist]]'' warned that the F-35 was in danger of slipping into a "death spiral," where increasing per-aircraft costs would lead to cuts in number of aircraft ordered, leading to further cost increases and further cuts in orders.[http://www.economist.com/node/18958487 "The last manned fighter."] ''The Economist'', 14 July 2011. Later that year, four aircraft were cut from the fifth "Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP)" order because of cost overruns.Capaccio, Tony. [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-26/pentagon-cuts-four-lockheed-jets-from-next-order-pentagon-says.html "Pentagon Cuts Four Lockheed Jets From Next Order, Pentagon Says."] ''Bloomberg'', 26 October 2011. In 2012, a further two aircraft were cut.Lerman, David. [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-02-13/pentagon-budget-for-2013-calls-for-two-fewer-of-lockheed-s-f-35-fighters.html "Pentagon Budget for 2013 Calls for Two Fewer of Lockheed’s F-35 Fighters."] ''Bloomberg News''. 13 February 2012. Lockheed Martin acknowledged that the slowing of purchases would increase costs.Gibbs, Walter. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/14/us-norway-lockheed-idUSTRE81D15H20120214 "U.S. slowdown on F-35 jet buy to raise cost: Lockheed."] Reuters, 14 February 2012. David Van Buren, U.S. Air Force acquisition chief, said that Lockheed Martin needed to reduce manufacturing capacity to match the reduced market for their aircraft.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/14/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSTRE81D1VJ20120214 "Pentagon, Lockheed see price of F-35 going up."] Reuters, 14 February 2012. However, the company said that the slowdown in American orders would free up capacity, which could be diverted to meet urgent, short-term needs of foreign partners for replacement fighters."Japan tells U.S. it may halt F-35 purchase if prices rise." ''Mainichi Japan''. 23 February 2012. Air Force Secretary Michael Donley said that no more money was available and that future price increases would be met with cuts in the number of aircraft ordered.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/21/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSBRE82K00T20120321 "'No more money' for F-35 cost overruns: Pentagon."] Reuters, 20 March 2012. Later that month, the Pentagon reported that costs had risen another 4.3 percent, in part because of production delays.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-lockheed-fighterbre82t03r-20120329,0,5046267.story "Pentagon says F-35 fighter delayed, costs rise 4.3 percent."] Reuters, 29 March 2012. In 2012, the purchase of six out of 31 aircraft was conditioned on progress of development and testing.Cox, Bob. [http://blogs.star-telegram.com/sky_talk/2012/05/pentagon-to-tie-f-35-orders-more-closely-to-development-and-testing-progress.html "Pentagon to tie F-35 orders more closely to development and testing progress."] ''Star Telegram'', 8 May 2012. In 2013, Bogdan repeated that no more money was available, but that he hoped to avoid the death spiral.{{cite web|url=http://defense-update.com/20130314_f-35-avoiding-the-death-spiral.html|title=F-35 – Avoiding the ‘Death Spiral’.|publisher=}} In 2014 it was reported that another eight aircraft would be cut from the following year's order.{{cite news |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-02-15/pentagon-said-to-seek-34-lockheed-f-35s-instead-of-42.html |title= Pentagon Said to Seek 34 Lockheed F-35s Instead of 42 |last1=Capaccio |first1=Tony |date=15 February 2014 |website= bloomberg.com |publisher= Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=18 February 2014}} Japan has warned that it may halt its purchase of the F-35 if the cost per aircraft increases and Canada has indicated it has not yet committed to purchase the aircraft.Campion-Smith, Bruce. [http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/1145684--canada-may-not-buy-f-35-fighter-jets-ottawa-admits "Canada may not buy F-35 fighter jets, Ottawa admits."] ''The Star'', 13 March 2012. Retrieved 23 March 2012.[http://www2.macleans.ca/2012/04/13/costly-obsolete-its-getting-hard-to-justify-buying-this-jet/ "The F-35: Not just costly but obsolete; To aviation nerds, the Joint Strike Fighter is looking more and more like an ugly mutt."] ''Maclean's'', 13 April 2012. The United States is now projected to spend an estimated $323 billion for development and procurement of the F-35, making it the most expensive defense program ever.[http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/military/jan-june10/defense_04-21.html "Pentagon's F-35 Fighter Under Fire in Congress."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009142954/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/military/jan-june10/defense_04-21.html |date=9 October 2010 }} PBS. Retrieved 22 August 2010. Testifying before a [[Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on National Defence|Canadian parliamentary committee]] in 2011, Rear Admiral Arne Røksund of Norway estimated that his country's 52 F-35 fighter jets will cost $769 million each over their [[Whole-life cost|operational lifetime]].[http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?DocId=5272974 "41st Parliament, 1st Session, Standing Committee on National Defence."] [[Parliament of Canada]], 24 November 2011. In 2012, the total life-cycle cost for the entire U.S. fleet was estimated at US$1.51 trillion over a 50-year life, or $618 million per plane.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-lockheed-fighterbre8310wb-20120402,0,2892759.story "Government sees lifetime cost of F-35 fighter at $1.51 trillion."] Reuters, 2 April 2012. In hopes of reducing this high lifetime cost, the USAF is considering reducing Lockheed Martin's role in [[Performance-based logistics|contractor logistics support]].Butler, Amy. "USAF Reducing Possible JSF Basing Locations." ''Aviation Week''. 2 March 2012. The company has responded that the Pentagon's lifetime cost estimate includes future costs beyond its control, such as USAF reorganizations and yet-to-be-specified upgrades.[http://www.thebaynet.com/news/index.cfm/fa/viewstory/story_ID/26946 "Lockheed Martin Statement on 2011 SAR Report."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401201013/http://www.thebaynet.com/news/index.cfm/fa/viewstory/story_ID/26946 |date=1 April 2012 }} Lockheed Martin. 31 March 2012. Delays have also negatively affected the program's worldwide supply chain and partner organizations as well.Williams, Peter. "Quickstep finds cash harder to come by." ''The West Australian'', 4 January 2012. In 2012, General [[Norton A. Schwartz]] decried the "foolishness" of reliance on computer models to arrive at the final design of aircraft before flight testing has found the problems that require changes in design.Weisgerber, Marcus. [http://www.defensenews.com/article/20120308/DEFREG02/303080012/DoD-Anticipates-Better-Price-Next-F-35-Batch "DoD Anticipates Better Price on Next F-35 Batch."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News''. 8 March 2012. In 2013, JSF project team leader, USAF Lieutenant General Chris Bogdan, said that "A large amount of concurrency, that is, beginning production long before your design is stable and long before you've found problems in test, creates downstream issues where now you have to go back and retrofit airplanes and make sure the production line has those fixes in them. And that drives complexity and cost".{{cite web|author=Four Corners By Andrew Fowler and Clay Hichens |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-02-18/pentagons-doubts-on-joint-strike-fighter/4524962 |title=Pentagon general issues warning on JSF blow-outs. |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=24 February 2013}} Bogdan remarked on the improvement in the program ever since Lockheed Martin was forced to assume some of the financial risks.{{cite web|url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2013/03/dn-3-star-christopher-bogdan-says-f35-comments-a-shot-across-the-bow-030513/|title=3-star: F-35 comments a ‘shot across the bow’.|publisher=}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} In 2012, in order to avoid further delays that would result from design changes, the U.S. DoD accepted a reduced combat radius for the F-35A and a longer takeoff run for the F-35B.Weisgerber, Marcus. [http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2012/03/airforce-defense-f35-radius-web-030612w/ "Schwartz defends reduced F-35 combat radius."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''AirForce Times''. 6 March 2012.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/pentagon-agrees-to-f-35a-combat-radius-reduction-369287/ "Pentagon agrees to F-35A combat radius reduction."] ''Flight International'', 8 March 2012. As a result, the F-35B's estimated combat radius was reduced by 15 percent.[http://www.defpro.com/news/details/33113/?SID=57f6edb6fae9052df9e3c58d31a4ba3e "JSFail? Not When the Pentagon Grades the F-35 on a Curve."]{{Dead link|date=November 2013}} ''DefPro.News'', 7 March 2012. In a meeting in Sydney, Australia in March 2012, the United States pledged to eight partner nations that there would be no more program delays.Regan, James. [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-lockheed-fighter-usabre82e0dn-20120315,0,3774659.story "U.S. seeks to ease concerns over F-35 delays, costs."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} Reuters, 15 March 2012. In May 2012, Lockheed Martin Chief Executive Bob Stevens complained that the Defense Department's requirements for cost data were themselves driving up program costs.[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/us-weapons-maker-pushes-back-at-pentagon.aspx?pageID=238&nID=22162&NewsCatID=345 "U.S. weapons maker pushes back at Pentagon."] Reuters, 1 June 2012. Stevens also said that a strike by union employees might result in failure to meet that year's production target of 29 F-35s.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-lockheed-strikebre8501hu-20120601,0,6170714.story "Lockheed hires temps at strike-hit Fort Worth plant."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} Reuters, 1 June 2012. Striking workers questioned the quality of work done by temporary replacements, noting that even their own work had been cited for "inattention to production quality," resulting in a 16% rework rate.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/06/08/lockheed-fighter-idINL1E8H8GO520120608 "Lockheed F-35 scrap rate at 16 percent – Pentagon."] Reuters, 8 June 2012. The workers went on strike to protect pensions, the cost of which had been the subject of negotiations with the Department of Defense over orders for the next batch of aircraft.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/15/us-lockheed-strike-idUSBRE85D1LI20120615 "Lockheed brings in more workers as strike drags on."] Reuters, 14 June 2012. These same pension costs were cited by Fitch in their downgrade of the outlook for Lockheed Martin's stock price.[http://money.msn.com/top-stocks/post.aspx?post=e3bd8705-f7c5-4260-8ae4-68cab07ff735 "Fitch lowers Lockheed Martin outlook to negative."] ''Trefis'', 13 June 2012. Stevens said that while he hoped to bring down program costs, the industrial base was not capable of meeting the government's cost expectations, given the current number of aircraft on order.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/19/us-lockheed-fighter-f-idUSBRE85I1VL20120619 "Lockheed says more orders key to cutting F-35 cost."] Reuters, 19 June 2012.Freeman, Ben. [http://pogoblog.typepad.com/pogo/2012/06/the-guerilla-warfare-of-pentagon-contractors.html "The Guerilla Warfare of Pentagon Contractors."] ''POGO'', 21 June 2012. According to a June 2012 Government Accountability Office report, the F-35's unit cost had almost doubled, with an increase of 93% over the program's original, 2001 baseline cost estimates.Wheeler, Winslow. [http://battleland.blogs.time.com/2012/07/09/f-35-nearly-doubles-in-cost-but-you-dont-know-thanks-to-its-rubber-baseline/ "How the F-35 Nearly Doubled In Price (And Why You Didn’t Know)."] ''Time'', 9 July 2012. In 2012, Lockheed Martin reportedly feared that the tighter policies of the Obama administration regarding award fees would reduce their profits by $500 million over the coming five years.Cox, Bob. [http://blogs.star-telegram.com/sky_talk/2012/07/pentagon-tightens-grading-standards-cuts-into-lockheed-profits.html "Pentagon tightens grading standards, cuts into Lockheed profits."] ''Star-Telegram'', 24 July 2012. This in fact occurred in 2012, when the Pentagon withheld the maximum $47 million allowed, for the company's failure to certify its program for tracking project costs and schedules.Capaccio, Tony. [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-10-26/pentagon-withholds-47-million-from-lockheed-on-f-35 "Pentagon Withholds $47 Million From Lockheed on F-35."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061245/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-10-26/pentagon-withholds-47-million-from-lockheed-on-f-35 |date=21 September 2013 }} ''Business Week'', 26 October 2012. The GAO also faulted the USAF and USN for not fully planning for the costs of extending legacy F-16 and F-18 fleets to cover the delay in acquiring the F-35.{{cite web|url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/news/gao-faults-air-force-on-cost-estimates-to-keep-f-1/nTF89/ |title=Air Force accused of wrong cost estimates to keep F-16s flying |work=Daytondailynews.com |first= Barrie |last= Barber |date= 26 November 2012 |accessdate=24 February 2013}} Because of cost-cutting measures, the U.S. Government asserts that the "flyaway" cost (including engines) has been dropping. The U.S. Government estimates that in 2020 an "F-35 will cost some $85m each, or less than half of the cost of the initial units delivered in 2009. Adjusted to today’s dollars, the 2020 price would be $75m each."{{cite web |url=http://media.aerosociety.com/aerospace-insight/2013/06/20/paris-air-show-day-3/8298/ |title=Paris Air Show 2013 – Day 3 |work=media.aerosociety.com |date=20 June 2013 |accessdate=16 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731091057/http://media.aerosociety.com/aerospace-insight/2013/06/20/paris-air-show-day-3/8298/ |archivedate=31 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |first=Tim |last=Robinson}} In 2013, Lockheed Martin began to lay off workers at the Fort Worth, Texas plant where the F-35s were being assembled.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/blog/morning_call/2013/01/lockheed-lays-off-110-workers-at-fort.html |title=Lockheed lays off 110 workers at Fort Worth assembly plant |work=The Business Journals |date=10 January 2013}} They said that revised estimates indicated that the costs of refitting the 187 aircraft built by the time testing concludes in 2016 would be lower than feared.{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/products/janes/defence-security-report.aspx?ID=1065975886&channel=defence&subChannel=business |title=F-35 concurrency costs not as great as feared, official says. |publisher=Janes |date=5 February 2013}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} The GAO's Michael Sullivan said that the company had failed to get an early start on systems engineering and had not understood the requirements or the technologies involved at the program's start.{{cite web|url=http://www.ipolitics.ca/2013/02/22/with-45-states-plugged-into-f-35-program-stealth-fighter-is-too-big-to-kill/ |title=With 45 states plugged into F-35 program, stealth fighter is too big to kill |work=Ipolitics.ca |accessdate=24 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017215526/http://www.ipolitics.ca/2013/02/22/with-45-states-plugged-into-f-35-program-stealth-fighter-is-too-big-to-kill/ |archivedate=17 October 2013 }} The Pentagon vowed to continue funding the program during budget sequestration if possible.{{cite news |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/12/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSBRE92B13520130312 |title= Pentagon vows to 'protect' funding for F-35 if possible |website= Reuters |first= Andrea |last= Shalal-Esa |date= 12 March 2013 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }} It was feared that the U.S. [[budget sequestration in 2013]] could slow development of critical software{{cite web |url=http://www.stripes.com/news/us/pentagon-s-budget-cuts-could-slow-f-35-program-congress-told-1.218146 |title=Pentagon’s budget cuts could slow F-35 program, Congress told |last1=Raghavendran |first1=Beena |date=25 April 2013 |work=Stars and Stripes |publisher=McClatchy Newspapers}} and the Congress ordered another study to be made on the software development delays.{{cite web |url=http://defensetech.org/2013/12/26/experts-to-study-f-35-software-delays/ |title=Experts to Study F-35 Software Delays |last1=McGarry |first1=Brendan |date=26 December 2013 |website=defensetech.org |publisher=Military Advantage |accessdate=4 January 2014}} As of 2014, software development remained the "number one technical challenge" for the F-35.{{cite web |url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140114/DEFREG02/301140029 |title=After 'Transformative' Year, F-35 Program Focuses on Software, Quantity |last1=Mehta |first1=Aaron |date=14 January 2014 |website=defensenews.com |publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation |accessdate=14 January 2014}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} In June 2013, Frank Kendall, Pentagon acquisition, technology and logistics chief, declared "major advances" had been made in the F-35 program over the last three years and that he intended to approve production-rate increases in September. Air Force Lt. Gen. Christopher Bogdan, program executive officer, reported far better communications between government and vendor managers, and that negotiations over Lot 6 and 7 talks were moving fast. It was also stated that operating costs had been better understood since training started. He predicted "we can make a substantial dent in projections" of operating costs.[http://www.airforcemag.com/DRArchive/Pages/2013/June%202013/June%2014%202013/F-35-No-Longer-the-Problem-Child.aspx F-35 No Longer the Problem Child]. Airforcemag.com (14 June 2013). Retrieved on 16 August 2013. In July 2013, further doubt was cast on the latest production schedule, with further software delays and continuing sensor, display and wing buffet problems.{{cite journal |url= http://aviationweek.com/awin/more-f-35-delays-predicted |title= More F-35 Delays Predicted |journal= Aviation Week |first= Bill |last= Sweetman |date= 1 July 2013 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }} In August it was revealed that the Pentagon was weighing cancellation of the program as one possible response to the budget sequestration{{cite news |url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-08-01/canceling-lockheed-f-35-said-to-be-among-pentagon-options.html |title= Canceling Lockheed F-35 Said to Be Among Pentagon Options |website =Bloomberg News |first= Tony |last= Capaccio |date= 1 August 2013 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }}{{cite news |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/02/us-usa-defense-weapons-idUSBRE97104P20130802 |title= Pentagon downplays prospects of cancelling F-35, bomber |website= Reuters |first= Andrea |last= Shalal-Esa |date= 1 August 2013 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }} and the [[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense]] voted to cut advanced procurement for the fighter.{{cite web |url= http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2013/08/03/is-lockheeds-f-35-about-to-become-a-victim-of-sequ.aspx |title= Is Lockheed's F-35 About to Become a Victim of Sequestration? |website= The Motley Fool |first= Katie |last= Spence" |date= 3 August 2013 |accessdate= 18 July 2014 }} On August 21, 2013, C-Span reported that ''Congressional Quarterly'' and the Government Accountability Office were indicating the "total estimated program cost now is $400 billion, nearly twice the initial cost". The current investment was documented as approximately $50 billion. The projected $316 billion cost in development and procurement was estimated through 2037 at an average of $12.6 billion per year. These were confirmed by Steve O'Bryan, Vice President of Lockheed Martin, on the same date.{{cite interview|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?314663-4/f35-lightning-ii-program |title=F-35 Lightning II Program |agency= c-span.org |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Steve |last=O'Bryan |interviewer=Greta Wodele Brawner |work=Washington Journal |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140525021155/http://www.c-span.org/video/?314663-4/f35-lightning-ii-program |archivedate= 25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Video not archived. In 2013, a RAND study found that during development, the three different versions had drifted so far apart from each other, that having a single base design might have come to be more expensive than if the three services had simply built entirely different aircraft, each tailored to their own requirements.{{cite web |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2013/12/17/5426931/report-f-35s-one-jet-apprach-more.html |title=Report: F-35’s one-jet approach more costly for military |last1=Capaccio |first1=Tony |date=17 December 2013 |website= star-telegram.com |publisher=Bloomberg News |accessdate=17 December 2013}} In 2014, the airframe cost went below $100 million for the first time, and the Air Force expected unit costs to fall.Isby, David C. "Status of the Joint Strike Fighter". ''Air International'', January 2014, p. 86. Accessed: 17 June 2014. A 2014 [[Center for International Policy]] study cast doubt on the number of indirect jobs created by the program, which has been a key selling point for the F-35 to Congress. Lockheed stood by their job numbers and said that their accounting was in line with industry norms.{{cite news |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-22/lockheed-martin-inflates-f-35-jobs-claims-nonprofit-says.html |title= Lockheed Martin Inflates F-35 Jobs Claims, Nonprofit Says |last1=Capaccio |first1=Tony |date=22 January 2014 |website= bloomberg.com |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=22 January 2014}} A January 2014 report by [[J. Michael Gilmore]] said that new software delays could delay Block 2B release by 13 months.{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/01/23/us-usa-lockheed-fighter-idUSBREA0M1L920140123 |title=Exclusive: Pentagon report faults F-35 on software, reliability |last1=Shalal-Esa |first1=Andrea |date=23 January 2014 |website= reuters.com |publisher=Thomson Reuters |accessdate=23 January 2014}} This estimate was reduced to 4 months in the DOTE report from November 2014.http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2014/pdf/dod/2014f35jsf.pdf The F-35 program office considered software to be the top technical risk to the program. The USMC was maintaining their expectation of an Initial Operational Capability by July 2015.{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/01/25/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSBREA0O01A20140125 |title=Pentagon F-35 program says 'laser-focused' on software issues |last1=Shalal-Esa |first1=Andrea |date=24 January 2014 |website= reuters.com |publisher=Thomson Reuters |accessdate=26 January 2014}} In 2014, U.S. Senator [[John McCain]] blamed cost increases in the program on "cronyism".{{cite news |url=http://news.yahoo.com/mccain-questions-u-government-industry-cronyism-lockheed-f-002426780--finance.html |title=McCain questions 'cronyism' on Lockheed F-35 program |last1=Shalal |first1=Andrea |date=16 June 2014 |website=news.yahoo.com |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=17 June 2014}} In 2014, the GAO found that the F-35 fleet would have operating costs 79% higher than the aircraft it was to replace.{{cite news |url=http://breakingdefense.com/2014/09/gao-draft-slams-f-35-on-unaffordable-costs-8-8b-over-legacy-fighters/ |title=GAO Draft Slams F-35 On ‘Unaffordable’ Costs: $8.8B Over Legacy Fighters |last1=Clark |first1=Colin |date=22 September 2014 |website=breakingdefense.com |publisher=Breaking Media, Inc. |accessdate=22 September 2014}} In 2014, the FY2015 Selected Acquisition Report stated that the program cost had increased 43% from 2001, with Program Acquisition Unit Cost up 68% and Unit Recurring Flyaway up 41%.Department of Defense (2015). [http://breakingdefense.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2014/04/F-35-2013-SAR.pdf Selected Acquisition Report (SAR) – F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Aircraft (F-35)]. Retrieved 25 May 2015. The F-35A's cost per flying hour in BY2012 dollars is $32,500 while the F-16C/D is $25,500, but each F-35A is expected to fly only 250 hours a year, compared to the F-16's 316 hours a year, resulting in the same yearly operating cost.Robbert, Albert A., [http://afcommission.whs.mil/public/docs/meetings/20130626/Cost%20of%20Flying%20Units%20in%20Air%20Force%20Active%20and%20Reserve%20Components%20-%20Albert%20Robbert%20-%20RAND.pdf Costs of Flying Units in Air Force Active and Reserve Components], USAF, ISBN 978-0-8330-7666-3, retrieved 25 May 2015 In December 2015, the FY2017 Selected Acquisition Report had revised the F-35A's cost per flying hour in BY2012 dollars to $29,806, in comparison with the F-16C/D's antecedent of $25,541, also in BY2012 dollars. This was a result of a decrease in the assumed cost per gallon of JP-8 fuel, a decrease in the fuel burn rate for the F-35A variant and a revised cost emiting relationship for hardware modifications.{{cite web|title=F-35 FY2017 Selected Acquisition Report|url=https://fas.org/man/eprint/F35-sar-2016.pdf|publisher=Department of Defense|accessdate=6 August 2016}} In July 2014, Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, and BAE Systems announced they would invest a combined $170 million in the program{{Clarify|date=February 2015}}, which was anticipated to result in savings of over $10 million per aircraft. This initiative was said to have set the project on track for an $80M (including engine) price tag per aircraft (F-35A) by 2018, when full production is scheduled to begin.{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/article/40736/farnborough-2014-officials-announce-f-35-affordability-measures |title=Farnborough 2014: Officials announce F-35 affordability measures |work=janes.com |accessdate=21 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225120602/https://www.janes.com/article/40736/farnborough-2014-officials-announce-f-35-affordability-measures |archivedate=25 February 2015 |df=dmy }} The December 2014 ''Selected Acquisition Report'' listed a cost decrease of $7.5 billion against a program cost of $391.1 billion ($320 billion in 2012 dollars). Lockheed Martin also stated that there would be an estimated decrease of nearly $60 billion to the operations and support costs.{{cite web|url=http://breakingdefense.com/2015/03/dod-acquisition-starting-to-begin-to-turn-corner-f-35-costs-down-2/|title=DoD Acquisition Starting To Turn Corner? F-35 Costs Down 2%|work=Breaking Defense|accessdate=21 March 2015}} The 2015 DoD annual report stated that the current schedule to complete System Development and Demonstration (SDD) and enter Initial Operational Testing and Evaluation (IOT&E) by August 2017 was unrealistic, instead the program would likely not finish Block 3F development and flight testing prior to January 2018. Based on those projected completion dates for Block 3F developmental testing, IOT&E would not start earlier than August 2018.http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2015/pdf/dod/2015f35jsf.pdf{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/test-report-points-f-35-s-combat-limits-0?NL=AW-05&Issue=AW-05_20160201_AW-05_373&sfvc4enews=42&cl=article_1|title=Test Report Points to F-35’s Combat Limits|work=aviationweek.com|accessdate=24 November 2016}} The Block 3I software was intended to be a revision of the Block 2B software to run on the updated Integrated Core Processor.{{cite news |url=https://www.f35.com/about/life-cycle/software |title=A Digital Jet for the Modern Battlespace |date=May 2015 |website=www.f35.com |publisher=Lockheed Martin Corporation |accessdate=24 March 2016}} Unfortunately, it resulted in a timing misalignment that reduced stability, requiring reboots in flight.{{cite news |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/air-space/strike/2016/02/10/f-35-chief-lays-out-biggest-development-risks/80202432/ |title=F-35 Chief Lays Out Biggest Development Risks |last1=Seligman |first1=Lara |date=10 February 2016 |website=www.defensenews.com |publisher=TEGNA |accessdate=24 March 2016}} By May 2016 the software had been improved to the point where it only crashed every 15 hours.{{cite news |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-chief-considers-fix-for-troubling-block-3i-soft-424650/ |title=F-35 chief considers fix for troubling Block 3i software faults |last1=Drew |first1=James |date=27 April 2016 |website=www.flightglobal.com |publisher=RBI |accessdate=26 April 2016}} Reboots were required over a third of the time for ground cold starts.{{cite news |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/air-space/strike/2016/05/09/f-35-test-flights-struggle-boot-up-but-jets-fly/84018338/ |title=F-35 Test Flights Struggle To Boot Up, But Jets Fly On |last1=Seligman |first1=Lara |date=9 May 2016 |website=www.defensenews.com |publisher=Defense News |accessdate=9 May 2016}} The following month saw 88 successful sorties untroubled by the stability bug.{{cite news |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/air-space/air-force/2016/06/21/f35-software-mountain-home-deployment/86191386/ |title=F-35 Software Runs Smoothly During Mountain Home Deployment |last1=Insinna |first1=Valerie |date=21 June 2016 |website=www.defensenews.com |publisher=Defense News |accessdate=21 June 2016}} ===Concerns over performance and safety=== A Lockheed Martin press release points to USAF simulations regarding the F-35's air-to-air performance against adversaries described as "[[Fourth generation jet fighter|4th generation]]" fighters, in which it states the F-35 is "400 percent" more effective. Major General Charles R. Davis, USAF, the F-35 program executive officer, has stated that the "F-35 enjoys a significant Combat Loss Exchange Ratio advantage over the current and future air-to-air threats, to include [[Sukhoi]]s".Kent, John R. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090105171230/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/news/press_releases/2008/0919ae_f-35settingrecordstraight.html "Setting the Record Straight On F-35."] Lockheed Martin, 19 September 2008. In September 2008, in reference to the original plan to fit the F-35 with only two air-to-air missiles (internally), Major Richard Koch, chief of USAF Air Combat Command’s advanced air dominance branch is reported to have said that "I wake up in a cold sweat at the thought of the F-35 going in with only two air-dominance weapons."Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&plckPostId=Blog%3a27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3ab1c3536a-8d96-481f-aef5-d6428ec6f9ca "JSF Leaders Back In The Fight."] ''Aviation Week'', 22 September 2008. Retrieved 3 July 2010. The Norwegians have been briefed on a plan to equip the F-35 with six [[AIM-120D]] missiles by 2019.[http://www.regjeringen.no/upload/FD/Temadokumenter/JSF_RBI-svar.pdf "Lockheed Martin briefing package for Norway."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012064324/http://www.regjeringen.no/upload/FD/Temadokumenter/JSF_RBI-svar.pdf |date=12 October 2012 }} ''Lockheed Martin'', 24 April 2008. Former RAND author John Stillion has written of the F-35A's air-to-air combat performance that it "can't turn, can't climb, can't run"; Lockheed Martin test pilot Jon Beesley has stated that in an air-to-air configuration the F-35 has almost as much thrust as weight and a flight control system that allows it to be fully maneuverable even at a 50-degree [[angle of attack]].Pocock, Chris. "LM defends F-35 JSF agility against critics." ''Aviation International News'', 15 June 2009.{{cite web|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2012/11/f-35a-achieves-max-angle-of-attack/ |title=F-35A achieves max angle of attack. |work=Australianaviation.com.au |date=20 November 2012}} Consultant to Lockheed Martin [[Lexington Institute|Loren B. Thompson]] has said that the "electronic edge F-35 enjoys over every other tactical aircraft in the world may prove to be more important in future missions than maneuverability".Thompson, Loren B. [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/f-35-fighter-confounding-critics-as-flight-tests-ramp-up?a=1&c=1171 "F-35 Fighter Confounding Critics As Flight Tests Ramp Up."] Lexington Institute, 1 March 2011. In an April 2009 interview with the state-run[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/6640215.html Beijing-based newspaper Global Times launches English edition], ''[[People's Daily]]'', 20 April 2009 ''[[Global Times]]'', Chen Hu, editor-in-chief of World Military Affairs magazine said that the F-35 is too costly because it attempts to provide the capabilities needed for all three American services in a common airframe.{{cite web |url=http://opinion.globaltimes.cn/commentary/2010-03/515744.html |title=F-35 fighter has become a clumsy white elephant |work=Global Times |date=24 March 2010 |accessdate=3 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317091704/http://opinion.globaltimes.cn/commentary/2010-03/515744.html |archivedate=17 March 2012}} U.S. defense specialist Winslow T. Wheeler and aircraft designer [[Pierre Sprey]] have commented of the F-35 being "heavy and sluggish" and possessing "pitifully small load for all that money", further criticizing the value for money of the stealth measures as well as lacking fire safety measures; his final conclusion was that any air force would be better off maintaining its fleets of F-16s and F/A-18s compared to buying into the F-35 program.[http://www.novatv.nl/page/detail/uitzendingen/7935/ "Amerikaanse twijfel over JSF" (in Dutch).] ''Nova'', 12 July 2010. Retrieved 22 July 2010. A senior U.S. defense official was quoted as saying that the F-35 will be "the most stealthy, sophisticated and lethal tactical fighter in the sky," and added "Quite simply, the F-15 will be no match for the F-35."Entous, Adam. [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703960004575427692284277852.html "U.S.-Saudi Arms Plan Grows to Record Size: Addition of Apaches, Black Hawks Swells Deal to $60 billion."] ''The Wall Street Journal'', 14 August 2010. Retrieved 16 August 2010. After piloting the aircraft, RAF Squadron Leader Steve Long said that, over its existing aircraft, the F-35 will give "the RAF and Navy a quantum leap in airborne capability."[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/EquipmentAndLogistics/FirstRafPilotFliesJointStrikeFighter.htm "First RAF pilot flies Joint Strike Fighter."]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} British Ministry of Defence via Defence News, 9 February 2010. In November 2009, Jon Schreiber, head of F-35 international affairs program for [[the Pentagon]], said that the U.S. will not share the software code for the F-35 with its allies.Wolf, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/24/us-lockheed-fighter-exclusive-idUSTRE5AN4JX20091124 "Exclusive: US to withhold F-35 fighter software codes."] Reuters, 24 November 2009. Retrieved: 12 September 2011.
