[http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA529057 "Survivability of the Next Strike Fighter", p. 23.] ''Aircraft Survivability: Susceptibility Reduction'' via ''Joint Aircraft Survivability Program Office (JASPO)'', Summer 2006. ==== Acoustic ==== In 2008, the Air Force revealed that the F-35 would be about twice as loud at takeoff as the [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle]] and up to four times as loud during landing.Alaimo, Carol Ann. [http://azstarnet.com/news/local/article_b8e6b612-1751-5554-8819-166f110f0f24.html "Noisy F-35 Still Without A Home."] ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'', 30 November 2008. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Residents near [[Luke Air Force Base]], Arizona and [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida, possible F-35 bases, requested environmental impact studies be conducted regarding the F-35's noise levels. In 2009, the city of [[Valparaiso, Florida|Valparaiso]], Florida, adjacent to Eglin AFB, threatened to sue over the impending F-35 arrival; this lawsuit was settled in March 2010.Moore, Mona. "Val-P to sue the Air Force." ''Northwest Florida Daily News'', 19 February 2009, Volume 63, Number 20, p. A1.Barlow, Kari C. [http://www.thedestinlog.com/news/legal-28112-nwfdn-fees-okaloosa.html "Val-p wants Okaloosa to reimburse F-35 legal fees."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} thedestinlog.com, 16 April 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405042733/http://www.thedestinlog.com/news/legal-28112-nwfdn-fees-okaloosa.html |date=5 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}}Nicholson, Brendan. [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/noise-triggers-legal-bid-to-down-jet-fighter/story-fn59niix-1226037459254 "Noise triggers legal bid to down jet fighter."] ''The Australian'', 12 April 2011. In 2009, testing reportedly revealed the F-35 to be: "only about as noisy as an [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] fitted with a Pratt & Whitney F100-PW-200 engine...quieter than the Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor and the Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet."Perrett, Bradley. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/F35-031209.xml "F-35 May Need Thermal Management Changes."] ''Aviation Week'', 12 March 2009. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} An acoustics study by Lockheed Martin and the Air Force found F-35's noise levels to be comparable to the F-22 and F/A-18E/F.[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:0yIuRIMUDwcJ:www.f-16.net/f-16_forum_download-id-11481.html+F-35+acoustics+test&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgfOwRZ9Cjk22IknVc6me97wPUsleYuw0aMTdia4Djkgx1C9hhiMOuSU_O7s1I8aaIh_NhSvO0kZlrK_05iNQvB_iCtyQWQ7d4uPEYz4oCoC6efEnxiqD1xkpsZ952kVNoAxgyE&sig=AHIEtbTRsgZXOeGUg90opGYn6e-msBU02w "Joint Communications Release, JSF Program Office & Lockheed Martin. Subject: F-35 Acoustics Based on Edwards AFB Acoustics, Test."] ''JSF Program Office & Lockheed Martin,'' April 2009. Retrieved 15 January 2011. A USAF environmental impact study found that replacing F-16s with F-35s at [[Tucson International Airport]] would subject more than 21 times as many residents to extreme noise levels.Alaimo, Carol Ann. [http://azstarnet.com/news/local/noisy-f--could-affect-thousands-in-tucson-study-finds/article_38ad2ab4-c151-5ee4-ae7c-9bc81c537a54.html "Noisy F-35 could affect thousands, study finds."] ''Arizona Daily Star'', 13 June 2012. The USN will need to redesign hearing protection for sailors to protect against the "thundering 152 decibels" of the F-35.{{cite web |url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140409/DEFREG02/304090026 |title=F-35 Forcing Navy To Develop New Hearing Protection For Flight Deck Crews |last1=MYERS |first1=MEGHANN |date=9 April 2014 |website= defensenews.com |publisher=Gannett Government Media |accessdate=9 April 2014}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} The Joint Strike Fighter program office found in October 2014 that the F-35B's take-off noise was only two decibels higher than a Super Hornet, a virtually indistinguishable difference to the human ear, and is even 10 decibels quieter when flying formations or landing.[http://defensetech.org/2014/11/25/f-35bs-no-louder-than-fa-18-super-hornets/ F-35Bs No Louder than F/A-18 Super Hornets] – Defensetech.org, 25 November 2014 ===Cockpit=== [[File:Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II mock-up instrument panel.JPG|thumb|F-35 cockpit mock-up]] The F-35 features a full-panel-width [[glass cockpit]] [[touchscreen]]{{cite web|url=http://wordlesstech.com/2012/07/19/lockheed-martins-f-35-lightning-ii-most-advanced-cockpit/|title="Lockheed Martin’s F-35 Lightning II most advanced cockpit" at wordlesstech.com|work=wordlessTech}} "panoramic cockpit display" (PCD), with dimensions of 20 by 8 inches (50 by 20 centimeters).Goebel, Greg. [http://www.vectorsite.net/avf35.html "The Lockheed Martin F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF)."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} vectorsite.net. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622162234/http://www.vectorsite.net/avf35.html |date=22 June 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} A [[Direct Voice Input|cockpit speech-recognition system]] (DVI) provided by [[Adacel]] has been adopted on the F-35 and the aircraft will be the first operational U.S. fixed-wing aircraft to employ this DVI system, although similar systems have been used on the [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B Harrier II]] and trialled in previous aircraft, such as the [[General Dynamics F-16 VISTA|F-16 VISTA]].Schutte, John. [http://www.afmc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123071564 "Researchers fine-tune F-35 pilot-aircraft speech system."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423232632/http://www.afmc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123071564 |date=23 April 2016 }} ''US Air Force'', 10 October 2007. A [[Helmet-mounted display|helmet-mounted display system]] (HMDS) will be fitted to all models of the F-35."Joint Helmet Mounted Cueing System." Boeing. Retrieved 23 November 2009. While some fighters have offered HMDS along with a [[head up display]] (HUD), this will be the first time in several decades that a front line fighter has been designed without a HUD.[http://www.rockwellcollins.com/news/page8813.html "VSI's Helmet Mounted Display System flies on Joint Strike Fighter."] ''Rockwell Collins'', 2007. Retrieved 8 June 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817153107/http://www.rockwellcollins.com/news/page8813.html |date=17 August 2011 }} The F-35 is equipped with a right-hand [[HOTAS]] [[side-stick|side stick]] controller. The [[Martin-Baker]] US16E [[ejection seat]] is used in all F-35 variants.[http://www.jsf.org.uk/JSF-UK-Industry-Team/Martin-Baker.aspx "Martin-Baker."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021165256/http://www.jsf.org.uk/JSF-UK-Industry-Team/Martin-Baker.aspx |date=21 October 2008 }} ''JSF''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. The US16E seat design balances major performance requirements, including safe-terrain-clearance limits, pilot-load limits, and pilot size; it uses a twin-catapult system housed in side rails."JSF" ''Martin-Baker''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. This industry standard ejection seat can cause the heavier than usual helmet to inflict serious injury on lightweight pilots.{{cite news |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/breaking-news/2015/10/14/f-35s-heavier-helmet-complicates-ejection-risks/73922710/ |title=F-35's Heavier Helmet Complicates Ejection Risks |last1=Seligman |first1=Lara |date=14 October 2015 |website=www.defensenews.com |publisher=TEGNA |accessdate=15 October 2015}} The F-35 employs an oxygen system derived from the F-22's own system, which has been involved in multiple [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] incidents on that aircraft; unlike the F-22, the flight profile of the F-35 is similar to other fighters that routinely use such systems.Peladeau, Jean. [http://www.lfpress.com/news/canada/2012/05/11/19748046.html "Pilots worry about F-35 oxygen system."] ''QMI Agency'', 11 May 2012.Bennett, John T. [http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/dotmil/2012/05/24/f-22s-oxygen-issues-raise-questions-about-f-35 "F-22's Oxygen Issues Raise Questions About F-35."] ''US News'', 24 May 2012. ===Sensors and avionics=== [[File:F-35 EOTS.jpeg|thumb|left|Electro-optical target system (EOTS) under the nose of a mockup of the F-35]] The F-35's sensor and communications suite has [[situational awareness]], [[command and control]] and [[network-centric warfare]] capabilities.{{cite interview |first=Eric |subject=George |interviewer= |title=F-35 avionics: an interview with the Joint Strike Fighter's director of mission systems and software |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-21/issue-5/news/news/f-35-avionics__an.html |date=1 May 2010 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |volume=21 |issue=5 |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The main sensor on board is the [[APG-81|AN/APG-81]] [[Active electronically scanned array]]-radar, designed by [[Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems]].[http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35aesaradar/ "APG-81 (F-35 Lightning II)."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems. Retrieved 4 August 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123033148/http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35aesaradar/ |date=23 January 2013 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} It is augmented by the nose-mounted Electro-Optical Targeting System (EOTS),[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/JointStrikeFighterElectroOpticalTar/ "Lockheed Martin Missiles and Fire Control: Joint Strike Fighter Electro-Optical Targeting System."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} Lockheed Martin. Retrieved 11 April 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106235314/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/JointStrikeFighterElectroOpticalTar/ |date=6 January 2009 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} it provides the capabilities of an externally mounted [[Sniper Advanced Targeting Pod]] with a reduced [[radar cross-section]].Scott, William B. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/10044top.xml "Sniper Targeting Pod Attacks From Long Standoff Ranges."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Aviation Week'', 3 October 2004. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415042219/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/10044top.xml |date=15 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}}Pappalardo, Joe. [http://www.origin.popularmechanics.com/technology/military_law/4339113.html "How an F-35 Targets, Aims and Fires Without Being Seen."]{{Dead link|date=November 2013}} ''Popular Mechanics'', December 2009. Retrieved: 6 April 2010. The AN/ASQ-239 (Barracuda) system is an improved version of the F-22's [[AN/ALR-94]] electronic warfare suite, providing [[sensor fusion]] of [[Radio frequency]] and Infrared tracking functions, advanced [[radar warning receiver]] including geolocation targeting of threats, [[multispectral image]] countermeasures for self-defense against missiles, [[situational awareness]] and [[electronic surveillance]], employing 10 [[radio frequency]] antennae embedded into the edges of the wing and tail.{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/19/Electronic-Warfare-Australias-mixed-record |title=Electronic Warfare: Australia's mixed record | Australian Defence News & Articles |publisher=Asia Pacific Defence Reporter |accessdate=24 February 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/217/Electronic-Warfare |title=Electronic Warfare | Australian Defence News & Articles |publisher=Asia Pacific Defence Reporter |accessdate=24 February 2013}} In September 2015, Lockheed unveiled the "Advanced EOTS" that offers short-wave infrared, high-definition television, infrared marker, and superior image detector resolution capabilities. Offered for the Block 4 configuration, it fits into the same area as the baseline EOTS with minimal changes while preserving stealth features.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-reveals-advanced-eots-targeting-sensor-for-416631/ Lockheed reveals Advanced EOTS targeting sensor for F-35 Block 4] – Flightglobal.com, 10 September 2015 Six additional [[Thermographic camera|passive infrared sensors]] are distributed over the aircraft as part of [[Northrop Grumman]]'s electro-optical [[AN/AAQ-37]] Distributed Aperture System (DAS),[http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35targeting/ "F-35 Distributed Aperture System (EO DAS)."] ''Northrop Grumman''. Retrieved 6 April 2010. which acts as a [[Missile Approach Warning|missile warning system]], reports missile launch locations, detects and tracks approaching aircraft spherically around the F-35, and replaces traditional [[night vision device]]s. All DAS functions are performed simultaneously, [[All-aspect|in every direction]], at all times. The [[electronic warfare]] systems are designed by [[BAE Systems]] and include Northrop Grumman components.[http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewnewspaged/articleid/3442641/pageid/2 "JSF EW Suite."] istockanalyst.com. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Functions such as the Electro-Optical Targeting System and the electronic warfare system are not usually integrated on fighters.{{cite web|last=Tirpak |first=John A |title=Slow Climb for the F-35 |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2012/October%202012/1012slow.pdf |publisher=AIR FORCE Magazine |accessdate=3 October 2012 |page=42 |date=October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120161246/https://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2012/October%202012/1012slow.pdf |archivedate=20 November 2012 |df=dmy }} The F-35's DAS is so sensitive, it reportedly detected the launch of an air-to-air missile in a training exercise from {{convert|1,200|mi|km|abbr=on}} away, which in combat would give away the location of an enemy aircraft even if it had a very low [[radar cross-section]].[http://breakingdefense.com/2014/06/a-gods-eye-view-of-the-battlefield-gen-hostage-on-the-f-35/4/ ‘A God’s Eye View Of The Battlefield:’ Gen. Hostage On The F-35] – Breakingdefense.com, 6 June 2014 [[File:AN-APG-81 Antenna, 2005 - National Electronics Museum - DSC00393.JPG|thumb|[[APG-81|AN/APG-81]] [[AESA]]-radar]] The communications, navigation and identification (CNI) suite is designed by Northrop Grumman and includes the [[Multifunction Advanced Data Link]] (MADL), as one of a half dozen different physical links.{{cite web |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-14/issue-5/features/special-report/f-35-jet-fighters-to-take-integrated-avionics-to-a-whole-new-level.html |title=F-35 jet fighters to take integrated avionics to a whole new level |date=1 May 2003 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The F-35 will be the first fighter with [[sensor fusion]] that combines radio frequency and IR tracking for continuous all-direction target detection and identification which is shared via MADL to other platforms [[Encryption|without compromising low observability]].Nativi, Andy. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/F35-030509.xml "F-35 Air Combat Skills Analyzed."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Aviation Week'', 5 March 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226061121/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/F35-030509.xml |date=26 December 2010 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} [[Link 16]] is also included for communication with legacy systems.[http://defense-update.com/20120727_israel-us-negotiate-450-million-f-35i-avionic-enhancements.html "Israel, US Negotiate $450 Million F-35I Avionic Enhancements."] ''Defense Update'', 27 July 2012. The F-35 has been designed with synergy between sensors as a specific requirement, the aircraft's "senses" being expected to provide a more cohesive picture of the [[battlespace]] around it and be available for use in any possible way and combination with one another; for example, the AN/APG-81 multi-mode radar also acts as a part of the electronic warfare system.Sherman, Ron. [http://www.aviationtoday.com/av/categories/military/845.html "F-35 Electronic Warfare Suite: More Than Self-Protection."] aviationtoday.com, 1 July 2006. Retrieved 22 August 2010. The Program Executive Officer (PEO) General Bogdan has described the sensor fusion software as one of the most difficult parts of the program.{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473499/program-executive-officer-describes-f-35-progress.aspx |title=Program executive officer describes F-35 progress |last1=Lyle |first1=Amaani |date=6 March 2014 |website= af.mil |publisher=American Forces Press Service |accessdate=6 March 2014}} Much of the F-35's software is written in C and [[C++]] because of programmer availability; [[Ada (programming language)|Ada83]] code also is reused from the F-22.{{cite web|url=https://journal.thecsiac.com/issue/53/158 |title=Hey C and C++ Can Be Used In Safety Critical Applications Too! |work=Journal.thecsiac.com |date=11 February 2001 |accessdate=24 February 2013}} The [[INTEGRITY-178B|Integrity DO-178B]] real-time operating system (RTOS) from [[Green Hills Software]] runs on [[Commercial off-the-shelf|COTS]] Freescale PowerPC processors.{{cite web |last=McHale |first=John |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-21/issue-2/news/news/f-35-joint-strike-fighter-leverages-cots-for-avionics-systems.html |title=F-35 Joint Strike Fighter leverages COTS for avionics systems|date=1 February 2010 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The final Block 3 software is planned to have 8.6 million lines of code.Warwick, Graham. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/awst/2010/06/07/AW_06_07_2010_p26-231580.xml&headline=Flight%20Tests%20Of%20Next%20F-35%20Block%20Underway "Flight Tests Of Next F-35 Block Underway."] ''Aviation Week'', 12 June 2010. Retrieved 12 June 2010. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In 2010, Pentagon officials discovered that additional software may be needed.Cox, Bob. [http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/11/21/2649040/pentagon-officials-to-meet-to.html "Pentagon officials to meet to address F-35 program's problems."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''[[Star-Telegram]]'', 21 November 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122044240/http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/11/21/2649040/pentagon-officials-to-meet-to.html |date=22 November 2010 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} General [[Norton Schwartz]] has said that the software is the biggest factor that might delay the USAF's initial operational capability.Reed, John. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/11/23/schwartz-concerned-about-f-35a-delays/ "Schwartz Concerned About F-35A Delays."] ''DoD buzz'', 23 November 2010. In 2011, Michael Gilmore, Director of Operational Test & Evaluation, wrote that, "the F-35 mission systems software development and test is tending towards familiar historical patterns of extended development, discovery in flight test, and deferrals to later increments."Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A0941e5b4-a3c7-4406-85f8-151f2ef34d6b&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "More F-35B Delays, Software Schedule At Risk."] ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 13 January 2011. The electronic warfare and electro-optical systems are intended to detect and scan aircraft, allowing engagement or evasion of a hostile aircraft prior to being detected. The [[Lockheed Martin CATBird|CATbird avionics testbed aircraft]] has proved capable of detecting and [[Radar jamming and deception|jamming radars]], including the F-22's [[AN/APG-77]].David A. Fulghum, Bill Sweetman, Bradley Perrett and Robert Wall. "Stealthy Chinese J-20 Vulnerable." ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 14 January 2011. The F-35 was previously considered a platform for the [[Next Generation Jammer]]; attention shifted to using unmanned aircraft in this capacity instead.Fulghum, David. "New Plan: NGJ To Go Unmanned." ''Aviation Week'', 25 January 2012. Several subsystems use Xilinx FPGAs;{{cite web|url=http://www.avionics-intelligence.com/articles/2013/06/ai-f35-fpgas.html|title=Tens of thousands of Xilinx FPGAs to be supplied by Lockheed Martin for F-35 Joint Strike Fighter avionics.|publisher=}} these COTS components enable supply refreshes from the commercial sector and fleet software upgrades for the [[software-defined radio]] systems. Lockheed Martin's Dave Scott stated that sensor fusion boosts engine thrust and oil efficiency, increasing the aircraft's range.{{cite news |url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20140725000012&cid=1101&MainCatID=0&utm_content=buffer429c5 |title=Japan needs to close bargain F-35 deal quickly |date=25 July 2014 |website= wantchinatimes.com |accessdate=24 July 2014}} Air Force official [[Ellen M. Pawlikowski]] has proposed using the F-35 to control and coordinate multiple [[unmanned combat aerial vehicle]]s (UCAVs). Using its sensors and communications equipment, a single F-35 could orchestrate an attack made by up to 20 armed UCAVs.[http://breakingdefense.com/2014/12/pawlikowski-on-air-force-offset-strategy-f-35s-flying-drone-fleets/ Pawlikowski On Air Force Offset Strategy: F-35s Flying Drone Fleets] – Breakingdefense.com, 15 December 2014 ===Helmet-mounted display system=== [[File:F-35 Helmet Mounted Display System.jpg|thumb|VSI Helmet-mounted display system for the F-35]] The F-35 does not need to be physically pointing at its target for weapons to be successful.[http://www.youtube.com/user/F35JSFVideos#play/uploads/7/CwvnhFgzIKI "F-35 Distributed Aperture System EO DAS."] YouTube. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Sensors can track and target a nearby aircraft from any orientation, provide the information to the pilot through their helmet (and therefore visible no matter which way the pilot is looking), and provide the [[seeker-head]] of a missile with sufficient information. Recent missile types provide a much greater ability to pursue a target regardless of the launch orientation, called "High Off-Boresight" capability. Sensors use combined radio frequency and infra red (SAIRST) to continually track nearby aircraft while the pilot's [[Helmet-mounted display|helmet-mounted display system]] (HMDS) displays and selects targets; the helmet system replaces the display-suite-mounted [[head-up display]] used in earlier fighters.{{cite web|url=http://gizmodo.com/260482/f+35-helmet-display-system-to-scare-the-bejeezus-out-of-enemies|title=F-35 Helmet Display System To Scare the Bejeezus Out of Enemies.|work=Gizmodo}} Each helmet costs $400,000.{{cite news|last1=Davenport|first1=Christian|title=Meet the most fascinating part of the F-35: The $400,000 helmet|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/04/01/meet-the-most-fascinating-part-of-the-f-35-the-400000-helmet/|website=WashingtonPost.com|accessdate=August 2, 2015}} The F-35's systems provide the edge in the "observe, orient, decide, and act" [[OODA loop]]; stealth and advanced sensors aid in observation (while being difficult to observe), automated target tracking helps in orientation, sensor fusion simplifies decision making, and the aircraft's controls allow the pilot to keep their focus on the targets, rather than the controls of their aircraft."JSF: the first complete ‘OODA Loop’ aircraft." ''Australian Defence Business Review'', December 2006, p. 23.{{refn|Quote: "Brigadier Davis was more forthright in his comments to media in Canberra, saying the ‘Raptor’ lacks some of the key sensors and the enhanced man-machine interface of the F-35."|group=N}} Problems with the Vision Systems International helmet-mounted display led Lockheed Martin-[[Elbit Systems]] to issue a draft specification for alternative proposals in early 2011, to be based around the Anvis-9 [[night vision]] goggles.Warwick, Graham. "Lockheed Weighs Alternate F-35 Helmet Display." ''Aviation Week'', 21 April 2011. [[BAE Systems]] was selected to provide the alternative system in late 2011.[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/lockheed-martin-selects-bae-systems-to-supply-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-jsf-helmet-display-solution-2011-10-10 "Lockheed Martin Selects BAE Systems to Supply F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Helmet Display Solution."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''BAE Systems'', 10 October 2011. The BAE Systems alternative helmet was to include all the features of the VSI system.Szondy, David. [http://www.gizmag.com/f-35-helmet-display-bae/20216/ "BAE Systems to provide new helmet display for F-35 pilots."] ''Gizmag'', 21 October 2011. However, adopting the alternative helmet would have required a cockpit redesign,Carey, Bill. [http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/singapore-air-show/2012-02-15/bae-drives-dual-approach-fixing-f-35-helmet-display-issues "BAE Drives Dual Approach To Fixing F-35 Helmet Display Issues."] ''AINonline ''. 15 February 2012. but in 2013 development on the alternative helmet was halted because of progress on the baseline helmet.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-jpo-drops-development-of-bae-alternative-helmet-391623/ |title=F-35 JPO drops development of BAE alternative helmet |work=flightglobal.com |date=10 October 2013 |accessdate=29 April 2014 |first=Dave |last=Majumdar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429220250/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-jpo-drops-development-of-bae-alternative-helmet-391623/ |archivedate=29 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In 2011, Lockheed Martin-Elbit granted VSI a contract to fix the vibration, jitter, night-vision and sensor display problems in their helmet-mounted display.[http://www.dailymarkets.com/stock/2011/11/17/lockheed-martin-awards-f-35-contract/ "Lockheed Martin Awards F-35 Contract."] ''Zacks Investment Research'', 17 November 2011. A speculated potential improvement is the replacement of Intevac’s ISIE-10 day/night camera with the newer ISIE-11 model.Jean, Grace V. [http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2011/August/Pages/NewSensorAimstoGiveF-35Pilotsa%E2%80%98WindowIntotheNight%E2%80%99.aspx "New Sensor Aims to Give F-35 Pilots a ‘Window Into the Night’."] ''National Defense Magazine'', August 2011. In October 2012, Lockheed Martin-Elbit stated that progress had been made in resolving the technical issues of the helmet-mounted display, and cited positive reports from night flying tests; it had been questioned whether the helmet system allows pilots enough visibility at night to carry out precision tasks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/30/lockheed-fighter-helmet-idUSL5E8LUJ4320121030 "Lockheed Cites Good Reports on Night Flights of F-35 Helmet."] ''Reuters.com'', 30 October 2012. In 2013, in spite of continuing problems with the helmet display, the F-35B model completed 19 nighttime vertical landings on board the USS ''Wasp'' at sea,{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/29/lockheed-fighter-testing-idUSL2N0GU03Z20130829|title=U.S. Marines see progress in F-35 testing despite challenges.|work=Reuters | date=29 August 2013}} by using the DAS instead of the helmet's built-in night vision capabilities, which offer at best 20/35 vision.{{cite web |url=http://insidedefense.com/Inside-the-Navy/Inside-the-Navy-09/02/2013/f-35b-pilots-conduct-night-shipboard-landing-without-night-vision/menu-id-81.html |title=F-35B Pilots Conduct Night Shipboard Landing Without Night-Vision |date=9 February 2013 |website=Inside the Navy |publisher=Inside Washington Publishers |accessdate=19 September 2013}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} In October 2013, development of the alternate helmet was halted. The current Gen 2 helmet is expected to meet the requirements to declare, in July 2015, that the F-35 has obtained initial operational capability. Beginning in 2016 with low rate initial production (LRIP) lot 7, the program will introduce a Gen 3 helmet that features an improved night vision camera, new liquid crystal displays, automated alignment and other software enhancements. In July 2015, an F-35 pilot commented that the helmet may have been one of the issues that the F-35 faced while dogfighting against an F-16 during a test; "The helmet was too large for the space inside the canopy to adequately see behind the aircraft. There were multiple occasions when the bandit would've been visible (not blocked by the seat) but the helmet prevented getting in a position to see him (behind the high side of the seat, around the inside of the seat, or high near the lift vector)."{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/damning-report-on-f-35s-dogfighting-problems-2015-7|title=Damning report on F-35's dogfighting problems – Business Insider|date=2 July 2015|work=Business Insider|accessdate=31 July 2015}} ===Maintenance=== The program's maintenance concept is for any F-35 to be maintained in any F-35 maintenance facility and that all F-35 parts in all bases will be globally tracked and shared as needed.[http://www.sldinfo.com/?p=18843 "F-35, Maintenance and the Challenge of Service Standardization."] ''Second Line of Defense'', 9 June 2011. The commonality between the different variants has allowed the USMC to create their first aircraft maintenance Field Training Detachment to directly apply the lessons of the USAF to their F-35 maintenance operations.Hawkins, Dan. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2012/07/mil-120727-afns01.htm "F-35 maintenance training spawns USMC's first air FTD."] ''USMC'', 27 July 2012. The aircraft has been designed for ease of maintenance, with 95% of all field replaceable parts "one deep" where nothing else has to be removed to get to the part in question. For instance the ejection seat can be replaced without removing the canopy, the use of low-maintenance [[electro-hydrostatic actuator]]s instead of hydraulic systems and an all-composite skin without the fragile coatings found on earlier stealth aircraft.Clark, Colin. [http://defense.aol.com/2011/11/03/why-lockheed-thinks-f-35-beats-boeings-f-18/ "Why Lockheed Thinks F-35 Beats Boeing's F-18."] ''Aol Defense'', 3 November 2011. The F-35 Joint Program Office has stated that the aircraft has received good reviews from pilots and maintainers, suggesting it is performing better than its predecessors did at a similar stage of development, and that the stealth type has proved relatively stable from a maintenance standpoint. This reported improvement is attributed to better maintenance training, as F-35 maintainers have received far more extensive instruction at this early stage of the program than on the [[F-22 Raptor]]. The F-35's stealth coatings are much easier to work with than those used on the Raptor. Cure times for coating repairs are lower and many of the fasteners and access panels are not coated, further reducing the workload for maintenance crews. Some of the F-35's radar-absorbent materials are baked into the jet's composite skin, which means its stealthy signature is not easily degraded.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-air-force-praises-early-performance-of-lockheed-martin-f-35-378578/ "US Air Force praises early performance of Lockheed Martin F-35."]''Flightglobal.com'', 6 November 2012. It is still harder to maintain (because of the need to preserve its stealth characteristics) than fourth-generation aircraft.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/stealth-isnt-becoming-obsolete-anytime-soon-379671/ "Stealth isn’t becoming obsolete anytime soon."] ''Flight International'', 30 November 2012. Retrieved 1 December 2012. However, the [[DOT&E]] Report on the F-35 program published in January 2015 determined that the plane has not, in fact, reached any of the nine reliability measures the program was supposed to achieve by this point in its development and that the Joint Program Office has been re-categorizing failure incidents to make the plane look more reliable than it actually is. Further, the complexity of maintaining the F-35 means that, currently, none of the Services are ready to keep it in working order and instead "rely heavily on contractor support and unacceptable workarounds." DOT&E found that the program achieved 61 percent of planned flight hours and that the average rate of availability was as low as 28 percent for the F-35A and 33 percent for the F-35B. The program created a new "modeled achievable" flight hour projection "since low availability was preventing the full use of bed-down plan flight hours." According to the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Financial Management, in FY2014, each non-test F-35 flew only 7.7 hours per month, which amounts to approximately one sortie every 5.5 days—for combat purposes, a sortie rate so low as to be crippling. Mean flight hours between removal (MFHBR) have increased, but are still only 59 percent to 65 percent of the required threshold. DOT&E found that mean corrective maintenance time for critical failures got worse for the F-35A and the F-35C over the last year. Structural cracking is also proving to be a recurring and enduring problem that is not yet resolved.{{cite web | url=http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2014/pdf/dod/2014f35jsf.pdf | title=FY 2014 Programs: F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) |date=15 January 2015 | publisher=The Office of The Director, Operational Test And Evaluation (DOT&E)}} ==Operational history== ===Testing=== The first F-35A (designated AA-1) was rolled out in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], on 19 February 2006. In September 2006, the first engine run of the [[Pratt & Whitney F135|F135]] in an airframe took place."Mighty F-35 Lightning II Engine Roars to Life." ''Lockheed Martin'', 20 September 2006. On 15 December 2006, the F-35A completed its maiden flight.[https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/7074259f3965fd0985256f43007b0964/7f70d66a0aaef181852573540049ead4?OpenDocument "F-35 First Flight."]{{Dead link|date=November 2013}} TeamJSF.com. Retrieved 10 October 2007. A modified [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737–300]], the [[Lockheed Martin CATBird]] has been used as an avionics test-bed for the F-35 program, including a duplication of the cockpit. The first F-35B (designated BF-1) made its maiden flight on 11 June 2008, piloted by BAE Systems' test pilot Graham Tomlinson. Flight testing of the [[STOVL]] propulsion system began on 7 January 2010."News Breaks: F-35B Engages Stovl Mode." '' Aviation Week'', 11 January 2010, p. 15. The F-35B's first hover was on 17 March 2010, followed by its first vertical landing the next day.Wolf, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/03/18/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSTRE62H4WF20100318 "F-35 fighter makes first vertical landing."] Reuters, 18 March 2010. During a test flight on 10 June 2010, the F-35B STOVL aircraft achieved supersonic speedsCavas, Christopher P. [http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2010/06/dn_jsf_supersonic_061410/ "F-35B STOVL fighter goes supersonic."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714034433/http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2010/06/dn_jsf_supersonic_061410/ |date=14 July 2011 }} ''[[Marine Corps Times]]'', 15 June 2010. as had the [[Lockheed Martin X-35|X-35B]] before.[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/transcripts/3004_xplanes.html "X-planes".] ''PBS: Nova transcript''. Retrieved 9 January 2010. In January 2011, Lockheed Martin reported that a solution had been found for the cracking of an aluminum bulkhead during ground testing of the F-35B.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.navytimes.com/news/2011/01/marine-f-35-lockheed-says-key-issue-is-fixed-011011w/ "Lockheed says it’s fixed key F-35B issue."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 10 January 2011. In 2013, the F-35B suffered another bulkhead cracking incident.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-addresses-pentagon-f-35-dote-report-381218/ |title=Lockheed addresses Pentagon F-35 DOT&E report |work=Flight International |date=18 January 2013}} This will require redesign of the aircraft, which is already very close to the ultimate weight limit.{{cite news |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-02-21/lockheed-f-35-for-marines-delayed-as-test-exposes-cracks.html |title= Lockheed F-35 for Marines Delayed as Test Exposes Cracks |last1=Capaccio |first1=Tony |date=21 February 2014 |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=21 February 2014}} [[File:First F-35 headed for USAF service.jpg|thumb|The first delivered USAF F-35 on its delivery flight to Eglin Air Force Base in July 2011.]] {{external media |align=right | topic = F-35B tests on {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1|6}} in 2011 | video1 = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6r_4UM6Eso Short TakeOff] | video3 = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=puj5lueXmJQ BF-04 vertical landing] }} By June 2009, many of the initial flight test targets had been accomplished but the program was behind schedule.Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.zinio.com/reader.jsp?issue=416083334 "Get out and fly."] ''Defense Technology International'', June 2009, pp. 43–44. During 2008, a Pentagon Joint Estimate Team (JET) estimated that the program was two years behind the public schedule, a revised estimate in 2009 predicted a 30-month delay.Cox, Bob. "Internal Pentagon memo predicts that F-35 testing won't be complete until 2016." ''Fort Worth Star Telegram'', 1 March 2010. Delays reduced planned production numbers by 122 aircraft through 2015 to provide an addition 2.8 billion for development; internal memos suggested that the official timeline would be extended by 13 months.Capaccio, Tony. [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/lockheed-f-35-purchases-delayed-in-pentagon-s-fiscal-2011-plan.html "Lockheed F-35 Purchases Delayed in Pentagon’s Fiscal 2011 Plan."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110005120/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/lockheed-f-35-purchases-delayed-in-pentagon-s-fiscal-2011-plan.html |date=10 January 2010 }} ''Bloomberg BusinessWeek'', 6 January 2010. The success of the JET led [[Ashton Carter]] calling for more such teams for other poorly performing projects.Bennett, John T. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4559411&c=POL&s=TOP "Carter: More U.S. Programs To Get JET Treatment."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} defensenews.com, 29 March 2010. Nearly 30 percent of test flights required more than routine maintenance to make the aircraft flightworthy again.Thompson, Loren B. [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/f-35-cost-rise-is-speculative-but-progress-is-real?a=1&c=1129 "F-35 Cost Rise Is Speculative, But Progress Is Real."] lexingtoninstitute.org, 12 March 2010. As of March 2010, the F-35 program had used a million more [[man-hour]]s than predicted.[http://startelegram.typepad.com/files/sasc-mar-11-final-transcript-carter_gilmore_fox.rtf "Senate Armed Services Committee Holds Hearing on President Obama's Fiscal 2011 Budget Request for the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Program."] ''Congressional Record'' via ''startelegram.typepad.com'', 11 March 2010. The United States Navy projected that lifecycle costs over a 65-year fleet life for all American F-35s to be $442 billion higher than U.S. Air Force projections."USAF Disputes Navy F-35 Cost Projections." ''Aviation Week''. Retrieved 3 July 2010. F-35 delays have led to shortfall of up to 100 jet fighters in the Navy/Marines team, although measures have been taken using existing assets to manage and reduce this shortfall.Grant, Greg [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/04/13/af-f-35-ioc-in-2016/ "JSF Production "Turned The Corner."] dodbuzz.com. Retrieved 15 April 2010. The F-35C's maiden flight took place on 7 June 2010, at [[Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base Fort Worth|NAS Fort Worth JRB]]. A total of 11 U.S. Air Force F-35s arrived in fiscal year 2011.Rolfsen, Bruce. [http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2010/05/airforce_force_structure_051610W/ "Jobs to change with focus on irregular warfare."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Army Times Publishing Company'', 16 May 2010. On 9 March 2011, all F-35s were grounded after a dual generator failure and oil leak in flight;Warwick, Graham. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3a27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3a433985ca-f77d-48db-86bf-81b9eecc11dc&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "In-flight Failure Halts F-35 Flight Tests."] ''Av Leak'', 11 March 2011. the cause of the incident was discovered to have been the result of faulty maintenance.Cavas, Christopher P. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6063313&c=AME&s=TOP "All F-35s Cleared To Resume Flight Tests."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''DefenseNews'', 25 March 2011. In 2012, Navy Commander Erik Etz of the F-35 program office commented that rigorous testing of the F-35's sensors had taken place during exercise Northern Edge 2011, and had served as a significant risk-reduction step.Branch, Ricardo, Army Sgt. [http://www.jber.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123156090 "Northern Edge fields new radar system."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027014134/http://www.jber.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123156090 |date=27 October 2013 }} ''Northern Edge Joint Information Bureau,'' 8 March 2012.Saiki, Lt. Col. Tracey. [http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/112953/continued-testing-of-f-35-jsf-sensors-a-success-at-northern-edge-2011.aspx "Continued testing of F-35 JSF sensors a success at Northern Edge 2011."] ''Af.mil.'' Retrieved 18 April 2012. On 2 August 2011, an F-35's integrated power package (IPP) failure during a standard engine test at Edwards Air Force Base led to the F-35 being immediately grounded for two weeks.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/08/03/360325/f-35-fleet-grounded-after-electrical-subsystem-failure.html "F-35 fleet grounded after electrical subsystem failure."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''[[Flight International]]'', 3 August 2011.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=7289794&c=AME&s=AIR "F-35s Grounded After Power Package Fails."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''[[Defense News]]'', 3 August 2011. On 10 August 2011, ground operations were re-instituted; preliminary inquiries indicated that a control valve did not function properly, leading to the IPP failure.[http://www.jsf.mil/news/docs/20110810_GROUNDOPS.pdf "Statement on JPO Reinstituting Ground Operations for the F-35 Program."] ''Joint Strike Fighter Program Office,'' 10 August 2011.[http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=7358985&c=AME&s=AIR "F-35 Fleet Cleared For Ground Operations."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 10 August 2011. On 18 August 2011, the flight ban was lifted for 18 of the 20 F-35s; two aircraft remained grounded for lack of monitoring systems.Lerman, David. [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-18/air-force-lifts-flight-ban-on-lockheed-f-35-fighter-jet-1-.html "Air Force Lifts Flight Ban on Lockheed F-35 Fighter Jet."] ''Bloomberg News'', 18 August 2011. The IPP suffered a second software-related incident in 2013, this resulted in no disruption as the fleet was already grounded by separate engine issues.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/25/us-lockheed-fighter-honeywell-idUSBRE91O11V20130225 "Honeywell to test some F-35 parts after smoke incident."] Reuters. On 25 October 2011, the F-35A reached its designed top speed of Mach 1.6 for the first time.[http://defensetech.org/2011/11/04/f-35-jsf-flight-test-update/ "F-35 JSF Flight Test Update."] ''Defense Tech'', 4 November 2011. Further testing demonstrated Mach 1.61 and 9.9g.Norris, Guy. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3a27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3acd242f57-3030-4871-b60b-764c1213fb1a&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "F-35A pushes to Mach 1.6."] ''Aviation Week & Space Technology'', 9 December 2011. On 11 February 2013, an F-35A completed its final test mission for clean wing flutter, reporting to be clear of flutter at speeds up to Mach 1.6.[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2013/february/130211ae_f-35a-completes-flutter-testing.html F-35A Completes 3-Year Clean Wing Flutter Testing Program] Lockheed press release, 11 February 2013 On 15 August 2012, an F-35B completed airborne engine start tests.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35b-completes-air-start-testing-at-edwards-afb-376071/ "F-35B completes air start testing at Edwards AFB."] ''Flight International'', 4 September 2012. During testing in 2011, all eight landing tests of the F-35C failed to catch the arresting wire; a redesigned tail hook was developed and delivered two years later in response.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.defensenews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2012301170010 "F-35C Tailhook Design Blamed for Landing Issues."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 17 January 2012.{{cite web |url=http://news.usni.org/2013/12/12/lockheed-new-carrier-hook-f-35 |title=Lockheed: New Carrier Hook for F-35 |last1=Majumdar |first1=Dave |date=12 December 2013 |website=usni.org |publisher=U.S. NAVAL INSTITUTE |accessdate=12 December 2013}} In October 2011, two F-35Bs conducted three weeks of initial sea trials aboard {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1|6}}."F-35B completes first sea trials on USS Wasp." ''navair.navy.'' Retrieved: 17 July 2012. On 6 October 2012, the F-35A dropped its first bomb,[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/picture-f-35a-releases-first-air-launched-weapon-377754/ "F-35A releases first air-launched weapon."] ''Flight International'', 17 October 2012. followed three days later by an [[AIM-120 AMRAAM]].[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/news/press-releases/2012/october/edwards-f-35a-completes-first-aim-120-amraam-internal-weapons-re.html "F-35A Completes First AIM-120 Amraam Internal Weapons Release."] ''Lockheed Martin'' press release, 22 October 2012. On 28 November 2012, an F-35C performed a total of eleven weapon releases, ejecting a GBU-31 JDAM and GBU-12 Paveway from its weapons bay in the first ground weapons ejections for the F-35C.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2012/11/mil-121130-nns01.htm "F-35C Lightning II Hits Weapons Testing Milestone."] ''Globalsecurity.org,'' 30 November 2012. On 5 June 2013, an F-35A at the Point Mugu Sea Test Range completed the first in-flight missile launch of an AIM-120 C5 AAVI (AMRAAM Air Vehicle Instrumented). It was launched from the internal weapons bay.[https://www.f35.com/news/detail/f-35a-completes-first-in-flight-missile-launch/ "F-35A Completes First In-Flight Missile Launch"]. Lockheed Martin, 7 June 2013. On 16 November 2012, the U.S. Marines received the first F-35B at [[Marine Corps Air Station Yuma|MCAS Yuma]], and the VMFA(AW)-121 unit is to be redesignated from a Boeing F/A-18 Hornet unit to an F-35B squadron.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/the-dewline//2012/11/mcas-yuma-recieves-first-opera.html "MCAS Yuma receives(sic) first operational F-35B."] ''[[Flight International]]'', 17 November 2012. A February 2013 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' article revealed that Marine pilots are not allowed to perform a vertical landing—the maneuver is deemed too dangerous, and it is reserved only for Lockheed test pilots.'''Time''' magazine, 25 February 2013, pp. 26–30, "The Most Expensive Weapon Ever Built", by Mark Thompson; restriction on vertical landings cited on page 28. On 10 May 2013, the F-35B completed its first vertical takeoff test.[https://www.f35.com/news/detail/f-35b-completes-first-vertical-takeoff/ "F-35B Completes First Vertical Takeoff"]. Lockheed Martin, 20 May 2013. On 3 August 2013, the 500th vertical landing of an F-35 took place.{{cite web|url=http://www.airrecognition.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=782 |title=Naval fighter aircraft F-35B STOVL for U.S. Marine Corps completes 500th vertical landing |work=airrecognition.com |date=7 August 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525023419/http://www.airrecognition.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=782 |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 18 January 2013, the F-35B was grounded after the failure of a fueldraulic line in the propulsion system on 16 January.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35b-grounded-after-fueldraulic-line-failure-381264/ |title=F-35B grounded after fueldraulic line failure |work=flightglobal.com |date=18 January 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Dave |last=Majumdar |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525030852/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35b-grounded-after-fueldraulic-line-failure-381264/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The problem was traced to an "improperly crimped" fluid line manufactured by [[Parker Hannifin|Stratoflex]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dodbuzz.com/2013/01/29/pentagon-crimped-line-caused-f-35b-grounding/ |title=Pentagon: Crimped line caused F-35B grounding |work=dodbuzz.com |date=29 January 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Michael |last=Hoffman |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525031140/http://www.dodbuzz.com/2013/01/29/pentagon-crimped-line-caused-f-35b-grounding/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/engineers-discover-culprit-behind-f-35b-fueldraulic-line-failure-381574/ |title=Engineers discover culprit behind F-35B fueldraulic line failure. |work=Flight International |date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=24 February 2013}} The Pentagon cleared all 25 F-35B aircraft to resume flight tests on 12 February 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.militarytimes.com/article/20130213/NEWS/302130306/Pentagon-clears-F-35B-to-resume-test-flights |title=Pentagon clears F-35B to resume test flights |work=militarytimes.com |date=13 February 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Aaron |last=Mehta |others=Image credit: Lockheed Martin |agency=The Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525031424/http://www.militarytimes.com/article/20130213/NEWS/302130306/Pentagon-clears-F-35B-to-resume-test-flights |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 22 February 2013, the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]] grounded the entire fleet of 51 F-35s after the discovery of a cracked turbine blade in a U.S. Air Force F-35A at Edwards Air Force Base.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21554331 |title= F-35 fighter jet fleet grounded by Pentagon |publisher=BBC |accessdate=23 February 2013 |date=22 February 2013}} On 28 February 2013, the grounding was lifted after an investigation concluded that the cracks in that particular engine resulted from stressful testing, including excessive heat for a prolonged period during flight, and did not reflect a fleetwide problem.Mount, Mike. [http://myfox8.com/2013/03/01/military-clears-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-to-fly/ "Military Clears F-35 Joint Strike Fighter to Fly"]. CNN, 1 March 2013.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35s-cleared-to-resume-flight-operations-382909/ "F-35s cleared to resume flight operations"]. Flight International, 28 February 2013. The F-35C Lightning II carrier variant Joint Strike Fighter conducted its first carrier-based night flight operations aboard an aircraft carrier off the coast of San Diego on 13 November 2014.{{cite web | url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84456 | title=F-35C Completes First Night Flight Aboard Aircraft Carrier | publisher=US Navy | date=13 November 2014 | accessdate=2014-11-28}} On 5 June 2015, the U.S. Air Education and Training Command Accident Investigation Board reported that catastrophic engine failure had led to the destruction of an Air Force F-35A assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida, on 23 June 2014. The third-stage forward integral arm of a rotor had fractured and broke free during the takeoff roll. Pieces cut through the engine's fan case, engine bay, internal fuel tank and hydraulic and fuel lines before leaving through the aircraft's upper fuselage. Leaked fuel and hydraulic fluid ignited the fire, which destroyed the rear two-thirds of the aircraft. The destruction of the airframe resulted in the cancelation of the F-35's international debut at the 2014 [[Farnborough Airshow]] in England, the temporary grounding of the F-35 fleet{{cite web | url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/story/military/2015/06/05/air-force-investigation-june-2014-f35-fire/28535269/ | title=AF investigation: Catastrophic engine failure caused F-35 fire | publisher=Airforce News | date=5 June 2015 | accessdate=5 June 2015}} and ongoing restrictions in the flight envelope.{{cite news|last1=Majumdar|first1=Dave|last2=Kjelgaard|first2=Chris|url=http://nationalinterest.org/feature/f-35-needs-bigger-more-powerful-engine-12491|title=F-35 Needs a Bigger, More Powerful Engine|work=The National Interest|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=29 July 2016}} On 19 June 2015 the [[RAF]] successfully launched two 500 lb [[Paveway IV]] precision-guided bombs, making the test the first time non-US munitions were deployed by the aircraft.{{cite news| title='F-35 Tests British Paveway IV Bomb'| url=http://awin.aviationweek.com/AWINLogin/tabid/1083/Default.aspx?returnurl=%2fArticlesStory.aspx%3fid%3dd5f973b4-2217-4450-98df-4519bf7ac35e| accessdate=24 June 2015| newspaper=''Aviation Week''| date=19 June 2015}} The US Marines declared the aircraft had met initial operational capability on 31 July 2015, despite shortcomings in night operations, communications, software and weapons carriage capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/better-five-years-late-than-never-u-s-marines-finally-ready-to-declare-f-35b-ready-for-limited-combat-duty|title=Better five years late than never: U.S. Marines finally ready to declare F-35B ready for limited combat duty|author1=Tony Capaccio |author2=Julie Johnsson |author3=Bloomberg News |date=31 July 2015|work=National Post|accessdate=31 July 2015}} However, [[J. Michael Gilmore]], director of the Pentagon’s Operational Test and Evaluation Office, criticized the operational trials as not valid. In an internal memo, Gilmore concluded "the exercise was so flawed that it 'was not an operational test … in either a formal or informal sense of the term.' Furthermore, the test 'did not—and could not—demonstrate' that the version of the F-35 that was evaluated 'is ready for real-world operational deployments, given the way the event was structured.'"{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/09/15/pentagon-weapons-tester-calls-f-35-evaluation-into-question|title=Pentagon weapons tester calls F-35 evaluation into question|author=Christian Davenport|date=15 September 2015|work=Washington Post|accessdate=29 September 2015}} On 11 April 2016 the Joint Program Office confirmed that the [[Royal Netherlands Air Force]] (RNLAF) had cleared its [[KDC-10]] aerial tanker to refuel the F-35, paving the way for the fighter’s international public debut at the RNLAF’s Open Dagen (Open Day) at Leeuwarden on June 10–11, 2016. The testing required the fighter to refuel in daylight, dusk and night, with 30,000 lb. of fuel being transferred during the tests.{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/netherlands-tanker-cleared-refuel-f-35? |title=Netherlands Tanker Cleared To Refuel F-35 |date=11 April 2016 |work=Aviation Week}} ===Training=== In 2011, the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation warned that the USAF's plan to start unmonitored flight training "risks the occurrence of a serious mishap".Schwellenbach, Nick. [http://www.pogo.org/resources/national-security/dod-memo-concerns-regarding-jsf-operational-utility-evaluation-training-flights.html "Concerns Regarding Plans for the Joint Strike Fighter to Begin Training Flights and Conduct an Operational Utility Evaluation."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''POGO'', 31 October 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030071648/http://www.pogo.org/resources/national-security/dod-memo-concerns-regarding-jsf-operational-utility-evaluation-training-flights.html |date=30 October 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} The leaders of the [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services]] called on Defense Secretary [[Leon Panetta]] to address the issue.[http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-s-senators-press-panetta-to-review-f-35-training-safety.html "U.S. Senators Press Panetta to Review F-35 Training Safety."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113195802/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-s-senators-press-panetta-to-review-f-35-training-safety.html |date=13 January 2012 }} ''Bloomberg News'', 9 December 2011. Despite the objections, expanded trial flights began in September 2012.Capaccio, Tony. [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-09-28/air-force-expands-f-35-trials-over-tester-s-objections "Air Force Expands F-35 Trials Over Tester’s Objections."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Bloomberg BusinessWeek'', 28 September 2012. [[File:F-35 Lightning II variants in flight near Eglin AFB in 2014.jpg|thumb|(From the top) 33rd FW F-35A, F-35B and F-35C near Eglin AFB in May 2014.]] The F-35A and F-35B were cleared for flight training in early 2012.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/awx/2012/02/27/awx_02_27_2012_p0-429863.xml&headline=USMC%20Near%20Start%20Of%20F-35%20Training%20Flights "USMC Near Start Of F-35 Training Flights."] ''Aviation Week''. 27 February 2012. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A military flight release for the F-35A was issued on 28 February 2012.[https://web.archive.org/web/20130802014635/http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123291745 "Air Force issues flight release for Eglin AFB F-35A]" ''www.af.mil''. 28 February 2012. Retrieved 5 May 2012 The aircraft were restricted to basic maneuvers with no tactical training allowed.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/first-air-national-guard-pilot-starts-transition-to-f-35-374470/ "First Air National Guard pilot starts transition to F-35."] ''Flight Magazine'', 17 July 2012. On 24 August 2012, an F-35 flew its 200th sortie while at Eglin Air Force Base, flown by a Marine pilot. The pilot said, "The aircraft have matured dramatically since the early days. The aircraft are predictable and seem to be maintainable, which is good for the sortie production rate. Currently, the flight envelope for the F-35 is very, very restricted, but there are signs of improvement there too." The F-35s at the base no longer need to fly with a chase aircraft and are operating in a normal two-ship element.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/eglin-f-35s-fly-200th-sortie-375794/ "Eglin F-35s fly 200th sortie."] ''Flight International'', 24 August 2012. On 21 August 2012, [[J. Michael Gilmore]] wrote that he would not approve the Operational Test and Evaluation master plan until his concerns about electronic warfare testing, budget and concurrency were addressed.[http://defense.aol.com/2012/08/28/pentagons-testing-czar-questions-f-35-programs-ote-plan/ "Pentagon's Testing Czar Questions F-35 Program's OTE Plan."] ''Aol Defense'', 28 August 2012. On 7 September 2012, the Pentagon failed to approve a comprehensive operational testing plan for the F-35.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/11/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSBRE88A04A20120911 "More problems raised at Pentagon F-35 fighter review."] Reuters, 10 September 2012. Instead, on 10 September 2012, the USAF began an operational utility evaluation (OUE) of the F-35A entire system, including logistical support and maintenance, maintenance training, pilot training, and pilot execution.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-to-start-f-35-operational-utility-evaluation-on-10-september-376217/ "USAF to start F-35 operational utility evaluation on 10 September."] ''Flight International'', 7 September 2012. By 1 October, the OUE was reported as "proceeding smoothly", pilots started on simulators prior to flying on 26 October.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-operational-utility-evaluation-proceeding-smoothly-377163/ "F-35 operational utility evaluation proceeding smoothly."] ''Flightglobal.com'', 1 October 2012. The OUE was completed on 14 November with the 24th flight, the four pilots involved having completed six flights each.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-unit-completes-f-35-oue-activity-379117/ |title=USAF unit completes F-35 OUE activity |work=flightglobal.com |date=16 November 2012 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Dave |last=Majumdar |others=Image Credit: Lockheed Martin |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525031901/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-unit-completes-f-35-oue-activity-379117/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} During the Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) phase of the aircraft, the U.S. had taken a tri-service approach to developing tactics and procedures for the F-35 using flight simulators prior to the type entering service. Simulated flights had tested the flight controls' effectiveness, helping to discover technical problems and refine aircraft design.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/simulation-plays-vital-role-in-building-f-35-tactics-and-aircraft-development-379336/ "Simulation plays vital role in building F-35 tactics and aircraft development."] ''Flight International'', 21 November 2012. Maintenance personnel have discovered that it is possible to correct deficiencies in the F-35, which is a software-defined aircraft, simply by rebooting the aircraft's software and onboard systems.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-air-force-praises-early-performance-of-lockheed-martin-f-35-378578/ "US Air Force praises early performance of Lockheed Martin F-35."] ''Flight International'', 6 November 2012. Air Force pilot training F-35A began in January 2013 at Eglin Air Force Base; the program currently has a maximum capacity of 100 military pilots and 2,100 maintainer students.[http://militarytimes.com/news/2012/12/air-force-f35-pilot-training-starts-next-month-eglin-121712/ "F-35 pilot training starts next month at Eglin>"] Militarytimes.com, 17 December 2012. On 23 June 2014, an F-35A experienced a fire in the engine area during its takeoff at Eglin AFB. In response, the Pentagon's Joint Program Office halted training in all F-35 models the next day,{{cite news|last1=Hennigan|first1=William J.|title=U.S. military grounds all F-35 jets after fire at Florida base |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/aerospace/la-fi-f-35-fire-grounded-20140626-story.html |publisher=The Los Angeles Times |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hennigan|first1=William J.|title=F-35 fighter jets to resume flights after fire led to grounding|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-f35-plane-fire-20140625-story.html|accessdate=2 July 2014|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|date=24 June 2014}} and on 3 July, the F-35 fleet was formally grounded.{{cite web|last1=Butler|first1=Amy|title=Blade 'Rubbing' At Root of F-35A Engine Fire|url=http://aviationweek.com/farnborough-2014/blade-rubbing-root-f-35a-engine-fire|website=Aviation Week|publisher=Penton Media|accessdate=14 July 2014}} The fleet was returned to flight on 15 July,{{cite news |url=http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2014/07/breaking-f-35-cleared-for-flight-2/?sf3711164=1 |title=BREAKING: F-35 Cleared For Flight |last1=Mehta |first1=Aaron |date=15 July 2014 |website=defensenews.com |publisher=Defense News |accessdate=15 July 2014}} but the engine inspection regimen caused the aircraft's debut at the Farnborough 2014 Air Show to be canceled.{{cite news |url=http://breakingdefense.com/2014/07/no-f-35s-coming-to-farnborough-safety-first-says-secdef-hagel/ |title= NO F-35s Coming To Farnborough; Safety First, Says SecDef Hagel |last1=Clark |first1=Colin |date=15 July 2014 |website=breakingdefense.com |publisher=Breaking Media, Inc. |accessdate=15 July 2014}}[http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140715/DEFREG02/307150027 "Pentagon: F-35 Will Not Go to Farnborough"]{{dead link|date=July 2016}}. Defense News In 2013, Lockheed Martin produced and delivered 36 F-35s, increasing the total number of F-35s produced to 101 (46 F-35As, 42 F-35Bs, and 13 F-35Cs).{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/lorenthompson/2013/12/23/2013-was-the-year-everything-went-right-for-lockheed-martins-f-35-fighter/|title=2013 Was The Year Everything Went Right For Lockheed Martin's F-35 Fighter|author=Loren Thompson|date=23 December 2013|work=Forbes|accessdate=21 March 2015}} However, in November 2014, the total number of F-35s produced, has increased minimally to 115.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} ===Basing plans for future U.S. F-35s=== On 9 December 2010, a media report stated that the "USMC will base 216 F-35Bs on the East Coast and 184 of them on the West Coast, documents showed." This report continued: "[[MCAS Cherry Point|Cherry Point]] will get 128 jets to form eight squadrons; [[MCAS Beaufort|Beaufort]] will have three squadrons and a pilot training center using 88 aircraft; [[MCAS Miramar|Miramar]] will form six operational squadrons with 96 jets and 88 F-35s will go to [[MCAS Yuma|Yuma]] for five operational squadrons with an additional test and evaluation unit.""Military plans to send jets to S.C., N.C., Calif., Ariz." The Associated Press, 9 December 2010, Susanne M. Schafer. In 2011, the [[USMC]] and USN signed an agreement that the USMC will purchase 340 F-35B and 80 F-35C fighters. The five squadrons of USMC F-35Cs would be assigned to Navy carriers while F-35Bs would be used ashore.Daniel, Lisa. [http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63158 "Plan Improves Navy, Marine Corps Air Capabilities."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529052624/http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63158 |date=29 May 2011 }} ''[[American Forces Press Service]]'', 14 March 2011.Cavas, Christopher P. [http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2011/03/navy-more-marines-to-fly-f35c-031411w/ "More Marines to fly carrier-variant JSFs."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428154152/http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2011/03/navy-more-marines-to-fly-f35c-031411w/ |date=28 April 2011 }} ''[[Marine Corps Times]]'', 14 March 2011. In February 2014, the [[U.S. Air Force]] announced that the first [[Air National Guard]] unit to fly the new F-35 Lightning II will be the [[158th Fighter Wing]] of the Vermont Air National Guard based at the Burlington Air Guard Station. The 158th currently flies [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]]s, which are nearing the end of their useful service lives. Burlington Air Guard Station is expected to receive 18 F-35As, replacing the 18 F-16 Fighting Falcons currently assigned. The F-35A is expected to arrive in 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.158fw.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123401944/|title=Feature - VTANG first Air Guard Base to receive F-35A|first=This story was written by Capt. Dyana|last=Allen|work=af.mil|accessdate=24 November 2016}} On 11 March 2014, the first F-35A Lightning II assigned to [[Luke Air Force Base]] arrived at the base. 16 F-35s are to be delivered to the base by the end of 2014, with 144 Lightning IIs to be stationed there, arriving over the course of the next decade.{{cite web|url=http://www.deagel.com/news/First-of-144-F-35A-Lightning-II-Stealth-Jets-Arrives-at-Luke-AFB_n000012469.aspx |title=First of 144 F-35A Lightning II Stealth Jets Arrives at Luke AFB |work=deagel.com |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525034824/http://www.deagel.com/news/First-of-144-F-35A-Lightning-II-Stealth-Jets-Arrives-at-Luke-AFB_n000012469.aspx |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473693/first-f-35-lightning-ii-arrives-at-luke-afb |title=First F-35 Lightning II arrives at Luke AFB > U.S. Air Force > Article Display |work=af.mil |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author=U. S. Air Force |others=Image credits:U.S. Air Force photo/Jim Hazeltine, 2xU.S. Air Force photo/Staff Sgt. Darlene Seltmann |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525035117/http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473693/first-f-35-lightning-ii-arrives-at-luke-afb |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 8 January 2015, the Royal Air Force base [[RAF Lakenheath]] in the UK was chosen as the first U.S. Air Force base in Europe to station two F-35 squadrons, following an announcement by [[the Pentagon]]. 48 F-35s, making up 2 squadrons, will add to the [[48th Fighter Wing]]'s already existing [[F-15C]] and [[F-15E Strike Eagle]] jets.[http://theaviationist.com/2015/01/09/uk-base-selected-to-host-first-u-s-f-35-jets-in-europe/ "RAF Lakenheath was selected as the first base to host USAFE F-35s."] ''The Aviationist'', Retrieved January 13, 2015. ==Procurement and international participation== {{Main article|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II procurement}} [[File:F-35 potential purchasers.PNG|thumb|350px|Participant nations:
{{legend|#000075|Primary customer: United States }} {{legend|#750012|Level 1 partner: United Kingdom }} {{legend|#227600|Level 2 partners: Italy and the Netherlands }} {{legend|#da8901|Level 3 partners: Australia, Canada, Denmark, Norway, and Turkey }} {{legend|#75edd4|Security Cooperative Participants: Israel and Singapore }} ]] While the United States is the primary customer and financial backer, the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands, Canada, Turkey, Australia, Norway, and Denmark have agreed to contribute US$4.375 billion towards development costs.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35-int.htm "F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Lightning II – International Partners."] ''Global Security''. Retrieved 7 April 2010. Total development costs are estimated at more than US$40 billion. The purchase of an estimated 2,400 aircraft is expected to cost an additional US$200 billion.Merle, Renae. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A38236-2005Mar15.html "GAO Questions Cost Of Joint Strike Fighter."] ''The Washington Post'', 15 March 2005. The initial plan was that the nine major partner nations would acquire over 3,100 F-35s through 2035.[http://www.jsf.mil/downloads/documents/JSF_PSFD_MOU_-_Update_4_2010.PDF "Estimated JSF Air Vehicle Procurement Quantities."] ''JSF.mil'', Updated as of April 2010. Sales to partner nations are made through the Pentagon's [[Foreign Military Sales]] program.Tae-hoon, Lee. [https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2012/03/205_106346.html "Seoul fears delivery delays of F-35 jets."] ''The Korea Times'', 6 March 2012. There are three levels of international participation.[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/F-35-Lightning-The-Joint-Strike-Fighter-Program-2012-07501/ "F-35 Lightning: The Joint Strike Fighter Program, 2012."] ''Defense Industry Daily'', 30 October 2012. The levels generally reflect financial stake in the program, the amount of technology transfer and subcontracts open for bid by national companies, and the order in which countries can obtain production aircraft. The United Kingdom is the sole "Level 1" partner, contributing US$2.5 billion, which was about 10% of the planned development costs[https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/75public/07CF737749FA9E5585256F3900720288?OpenDocument "JSF Global Partners."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071004212446/https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/75public/07CF737749FA9E5585256F3900720288?OpenDocument |date=4 October 2007 }} teamjsf.com. Retrieved 30 March 2007. under the 1995 [[Memorandum of Understanding]] that brought the UK into the project."US, UK sign JAST agreement." ''Aerospace Daily'' New York: McGraw-Hill, 25 November 1995, p. 451. Level 2 partners are Italy, which is contributing US$1 billion; and the Netherlands, US$800 million. Level 3 partners are Turkey, US$195 million; Canada, US$160 million; Australia, US$144 million; Norway, US$122 million and Denmark, US$110 million. Israel and Singapore have joined as Security Cooperative Participants (SCP).Schnasi, Katherine V. [http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d04554.pdf "Joint Strike Fighter Acquisition: Observations on the Supplier Base."] ''US Accounts Office''. Retrieved 8 February 2006.[http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/ad-ad.nsf/eng/ad03863.html "Industry Canada F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Canada's Next Generation Fighter Capability."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922154022/http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/ad-ad.nsf/eng/ad03863.html |date=22 September 2010 }} ic.gc.ca. Retrieved 25 November 2010.''Combat Aircraft Monthly'', September 2010, p. 24. Japan announced on 20 December 2011 its intent to purchase 42 F-35s with deliveries beginning in 2016 to replace the [[F-4 Phantom II]]; Japan seeks 38 F-35s, to be assembled domestically.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16259895 "US Lockheed Martin F-35 chosen as Japan fighter jet."] BBC News, 20 December 2011. Retrieved: 20 December 2011. By 2012, many changes had occurred in the order book. Italy became the first country to announce a reduction of its overall fleet procurement, cutting its buy from 131 to 90 aircraft. Other nations reduced initial purchases or delayed orders while still intending to purchase the same final numbers. The United States canceled the initial purchase of 13 F-35s and postponed orders for another 179. The United Kingdom cut its initial order and delayed a decision on future orders. Australia decided to buy the [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]] as an interim measure. Turkey also cut its initial order of four aircraft to two, but confirmed plans to purchase 100 F-35As.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/23/turkey-f35-lockheed-idUSL5E8DN2IM20120223 "Update 1-Turkey keeps plan to buy 100 F-35 fighter jets."] Reuters, 23 February 2012.[http://www.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=378853#.T-xxLsr4JfA "Turkey plans to buy 100 F-35 jet fighters."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521004950/http://www.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=378853#.T-xxLsr4JfA |date=21 May 2012 }} turkishpress.com, 24 February 2012. Turkey will buy four F-35s to be delivered in 2015 and 2016, while the order may be increased from 100 to 120 aircraft.[http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/141212/turkey-to-buy-two-planes-in-second-f-35-shipment.html "Turkey to Buy Two Planes in Second F-35 Shipment."] ''turkishweekly.net,'' 4 September 2012. These changes resulted in increased procurement prices, and increased the likelihood of further cuts.Harper, Tim. [http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/1131391--tim-harper-the-conservatives-and-their-f-35-fairy-tale "Tim Harper: The Conservatives and their F-35 fairy tale."] ''[[Toronto Star]]'', 14 February 2012.Vasarri, Chiara. [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-02-15/italy-to-cut-f-35-fighter-jet-orders-as-part-of-defense-revamp.html "Italy to Cut F-35 Fighter Jet Orders as Part of Defense Revamp."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Bloomberg Business Week'', 14 February 2012. On 3 April 2012, the [[Auditor General of Canada]] [[Michael Ferguson (Auditor General)|Michael Ferguson]] published a report outlining problems with [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Canadian procurement|Canada's procurement of the jet]], including misinformation over the final cost. According to the Auditor General, the government knowingly understated the final price of the 65 jets by $10 billion.Postmedia News. [http://www.canada.com/timeline+Canada+involvement+program/6419249/story.html "A timeline on Canada's involvement in the F-35 program."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410034623/http://www.canada.com/timeline+Canada+involvement+program/6419249/story.html |date=10 April 2012 }} ''[[Canada.com]]'', 5 April 2012. Canada's Conservative government had stated it would not reduce its order, and anticipated a $75–80 million unit cost; the procurement was termed a "scandal" and "fiasco" by the media and faced a full review to determine any Canadian F-35 purchase.[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/video/video-mps-hold-mackay-to-account-in-f-35-scandal/article2392358/ "Video: MPs hold Mackay to account in F-35 scandal."] [[The Canadian Press]] via ''[[Globe and Mail]]'', 4 April 2012.Coyne, Andrew. [http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/04/andrew-coyne-the-f-35-affair-is-a-fiasco-from-top-to-bottom/ "Peeling back the layers of misconduct in the F-35 fiasco."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404231411/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/04/andrew-coyne-the-f-35-affair-is-a-fiasco-from-top-to-bottom/ |date=4 April 2012 }} ''[[National Post]]'', 4 April 2012.[http://www.cbc.ca/thenational/indepthanalysis/atissue/story/2012/04/05/thenational-atissue-040512.html "The F-35 Fiasco."] ''[[CBC News]]'', 5 April 2012. On 13 December 2012, in a scathing editorial published by [[CBC News]], journalist [[Brian Stewart (journalist)|Brian Stewart]] termed the F-35 project a "global wrecking ball" for its runaway costs and lack of affordability for many participating nations.Stewart, Brian. [http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/12/12/f-vp-stewart-f35-jets.html "Super-costly F-35s, a global wrecking ball."] ''[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]'', 13 December 2012. In May 2013, Lockheed Martin declared that Turkey is projected to earn $12 billion from licensed production of F-35 components.{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/f-35-project-to-earn-turkey-12-billion.aspx?pageID=238&nid=46581&NewsCatID=345 |title=F-35 project to ‘earn Turkey $12 billion’ |work=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=30 May 2013 |author= |agency=Reuters |others=Image credit: Reuters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525035843/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/f-35-project-to-earn-turkey-12-billion.aspx?pageID=238&nid=46581&NewsCatID=345 |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.i4u.com/2013/05/lockheed-martin-f-35-lightning-ii/turkey-f-35-12-project-billion-earn |title=F-35 project to ‘earn Turkey $12 billion’ |work=I4u.com |date=9 May 2013 |accessdate=30 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130630202726/http://www.i4u.com/2013/05/lockheed-martin-f-35-lightning-ii/turkey-f-35-12-project-billion-earn |archivedate=30 June 2013 }} In November 2014, the United Kingdom confirmed its first order for 14 F-35Bs to be delivered in 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20141124/DEFREG01/311240016/UK-Confirms-First-F-35-Orders | title=UK Confirms First F-35 Orders | publisher=DefenseNews | date=24 Nov 2014 | accessdate=2014-11-28}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} === Procurement costs === Estimated cost of airplane in Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) and Full Rate Production (FRP) batches: {|class="wikitable" |- | '''Contract date''' | '''Batch''' | '''Number and Variant''' | '''Unit cost (millions)''' | '''Notes''' |- | Apr 2007 | LRIP-1 | 2 F-35A | $221.2[http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/12/17/f-35-lrip-4-costs-detailed F-35 LRIP-4 Costs Detailed] DoDBuzz.com 17 Dec 2010
