(target price incl. engine) | Costs are estimated as of 2012. |} ==Variants== [[File:F-35 A B C Config.png|thumb|Configuration of the three original F-35 variants]] The F-35 is being built in three different main versions to suit various combat missions. ===F-35A=== The F-35A is the conventional takeoff and landing ([[CTOL]]) variant intended for the U.S. Air Force and other air forces. It is the smallest, lightest F-35 version and is the only variant equipped with an internal cannon, the [[GAU-12 Equalizer#GAU-22/A|GAU-22/A]]. This [[25 mm caliber|25 mm]] cannon is a development of the [[GAU-12 Equalizer|GAU-12]] carried by the USMC's [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B Harrier II]]. It is designed for increased effectiveness against ground targets compared to the [[20 mm caliber|20 mm]] [[M61 Vulcan]] cannon carried by other USAF fighters. [[File:A U.S. Air Force pilot navigates an F-35A Lightning II aircraft assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron, 33rd Fighter Wing into position to refuel with a KC-135 Stratotanker assigned to the 336th Air Refueling 130516-F-XL333-496.jpg|thumb|left|US Air Force F-35A maneuvers to refuel from a KC-135]] The F-35A is expected to match the F-16 in maneuverability and instantaneous high-g performance, and outperform it in stealth, payload, range on internal fuel, avionics, operational effectiveness, supportability, and survivability.Pike, John. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35a.htm "F-35A Joint Strike Fighter."] Globalsecurity.org. Retrieved 23 November 2009. It is expected to match an F-16 that is carrying the usual external fuel tank in acceleration performance.[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/aeronautics/afa/beesley-interview.html "Flying The F-35: An Interview With Jon Beesley, F-35 Chief Test Pilot."] lockheedmartin.com. Retrieved 25 November 2010. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The A variant is primarily intended to replace the USAF's [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16 Fighting Falcon]]. At one point it was also intended to replace the [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10 Thunderbolt II]] starting in 2028.Hebert, Adam J. [http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/July%202007/0707lightning.aspx "Lightning II: So Far, So Good."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221095128/http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/July%202007/0707lightning.aspx |date=21 February 2009 }} ''airforce-magazine.com'', Air Force Association, Volume 90, Issue 7, July 2007. Retrieved 3 December 2008.Laurenzo, Ron. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2003/030609-a-10-retire01.htm "Air Force: No Plan To Retire A-10."] GlobalSecurity.org, Defense Weekly, 9 June 2003. Retrieved 3 December 2008. The F-35A can be outfitted to receive fuel via either of the two main aerial refueling methods; this was a consideration in the Canadian procurement and a deciding factor for the Japanese purchase.Waldron, Greg. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/in-focus-tokyo-casts-wary-eye-on-chinese-airpower-developments-375007/ "IN FOCUS: Tokyo casts wary eye on Chinese airpower developments."] ''Flight International'', 2 August 2012.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/10/23/f-35-communication-problem.html "F-35s face communication problems in Arctic."] The Canadian Press, 23 October 2011.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2012/06/19/lockheeds-comprehensive-qa-on-the-f-35/ "Lockheed’s comprehensive Q&A on the F-35."] ''DoD Buzz'', 19 June 2012. On 18 December 2013, the Netherlands became the second partner country to operate the F-35A, when Maj. Laurens J.W. Vijge of the [[Royal Netherlands Air Force]] took off from Eglin Air Force Base.{{cite web|url= http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/first-royal-netherlands-air-force-f-35-pilot-takes-flight/ |title= First Royal Netherlands Air Force F-35 Pilot Takes Flight |work= defensemedianetwork.com |accessdate=21 January 2014}} On 27 January 2014, General [[Gilmary M. Hostage III|Mike Hostage]], head of [[Air Combat Command]], stated he would fight "to the death" to not have a single plane of the USAF's planned 1,763 F-35 purchase be cut, because the allies and partners of the US got "weak in the knees" when seeing the USAF "back away" from the F-35. He said the F-15 and F-16 fleets would become tactically obsolete in the middle of the next decade regardless of improvements. Hostage also commented that the F-35 would be "irrelevant" without the F-22 fleet being viable as the F-35 was not an air superiority fighter,{{cite web |url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/article/20140202/NEWS04/302020005/Air-Combat-Command-s-challenge-Buy-new-modernize-older-aircraft |title=Air Combat Command's challenge: Buy new or modernize older aircraft |work=airforcetimes.com |date=2 February 2014 |accessdate=22 March 2014 |first=Aaron |last=Mehta |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.airforcetimes.com%2Farticle%2F20140202%2FNEWS04%2F302020005%2FAir-Combat-Command-s-challenge-Buy-new-modernize-older-aircraft&date=2014-03-22 |archivedate=22 March 2014 |deadurl=no}} and that an F-35 pilot who enters a dogfight has made a mistake.{{cite news |url=http://breakingdefense.com/2014/06/gen-mike-hostage-on-the-f-35-no-growlers-needed-when-war-starts/ |title= Gen. Mike Hostage On The F-35; No Growlers Needed When War Starts |last1=Clark |first1=Colin |date=June 6, 2014 |website=breakingdefense.com |publisher=Breaking Media, Inc |accessdate=3 July 2015}} The F-35As for the [[Royal Norwegian Air Force]] will have [[drag chute]] installed. Norway will be the first country to adopt the drag chute pod.{{cite web|url=http://www.codeonemagazine.com/article.html?item_id=138|title=Cold Stops|publisher=}} On 2 August 2016 the U.S. Air Force declared the F-35A basic combat ready.{{cite web|website=Military Embedded Systems|url=http://mil-embedded.com/news/f-35a-lightning-ii-declared-combat-ready-by-air-force/|title=F-35A Lightning II declared combat ready by Air Force|date=2016-08-02}} The [[34th Fighter Squadron]] located at [[Hill Air Force Base]], Utah, has at least 12 combat-ready jets capable of global deployment. F-35A is scheduled to be full combat ready in 2017 with its 3F software upgrade. [[Air Combat Command]] will initially deploy F-35A to [[Exercise Red Flag|Red Flag exercises]] and as a "theater security package" to Europe and the Asia-Pacific. It will probably not be fighting the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] in the Middle East earlier than 2017, but ACC commander General [[Herbert J. Carlisle|Herbert "Hawk" Carlisle]] wouldn't mind deploying them earlier.{{cite web|website=Defense News|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/breaking-news/2016/08/02/f35-ioc-air-force-operational-acc-combat/87948142/|title=Air Force Declares F-35A Ready for Combat|date=2016-08-02}} ===F-35B=== [[File:US Navy 111005-N-ZZ999-055 The F-35B Lightning 11 takes off from the amphibious assault ship USS Wasp (LHD 1).jpg|thumb|F-35B short-takeoff from {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1|6}} during its first sea trials, October 2011.]] The F-35B is the short takeoff and vertical landing ([[STOVL]]) variant of the aircraft. Similar in size to the A variant, the B sacrifices about a third of the A variant's fuel volume to accommodate the [[Rolls-Royce LiftSystem|vertical flight system]]. Vertical takeoffs and landings are riskier because of threats such as [[foreign object damage]].Hancock, Ben D. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/1997/Hancock.htm "The STOVL Joint Strike Fighter in Support of the 21st Century Marine Corps."] ''USMC'', 1997.{{cite web |url=http://www.usace-isc.org/presentation/Geotech%20and%20Materials%20II/Constructability_of_a_High_Temperature_Concrete_Pad_Bly_Peter.pdf |title=Constructability of a High Temperature Concrete Pad |work=usace-isc.org|publisher=Geotechnical & Structures Laboratory US Army Engineer Research & Development Center (ERDC) |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Peter |last=Bly}}{{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Whereas the F-35A is stressed to 9 g,Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.zinio.com/express3?issue=368748439 "Numbers Crunch: True cost of JSF program remains to be seen."] ''Defense Technology International'', February 2009, p. 22.[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/f-35-hmds-pulls-the-gs-04088/ "F-35 HMDS Pulls the Gs".] ''Defense Industry Daily'', 25 October 2007. the F-35B's stress goal is 7 g. {{asof|2014}}, the F-35B is limited to 4.5 g and 400 knots. The next software upgrade includes weapons, and allows 5.5 g and Mach 1.2, with a final target of 7 g and Mach 1.6.Norris, Guy. "[http://aviationweek.com/blog/pilot-reaction-flying-f-35b Pilot reaction to flying the F-35B]" ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'', 24 April 2014. Accessed: 15 September 2014. [http://web.archive.org/web/20140727190007/http://aviationweek.com/blog/pilot-reaction-flying-f-35b Archived] on 27 September 2014 The first test flight of the F-35B was conducted on 11 June 2008.Norris, Guy and Graham Warwick. "F-35B First Flight Boosts JSF as F-22 Loses Supporters." ''Aviation Week'', 15 June 2008. Another milestone, the first successful ski-jump launch was carried out by [[BAE]] test pilot Peter Wilson on 24 June 2015.{{cite news| last=Alison| first=George| title='F-35B successfully performs first launch from ski-jump'|url=https://ukdefencejournal.org.uk/f-35b-successfully-performs-first-launch-from-ski-jump/|accessdate=24 June 2015| newspaper=''UK Defense Journal''| date=24 June 2015}} Unlike other variants, the F-35B has no landing hook. The "STOVL/HOOK" control instead engages conversion between normal and vertical flight.[http://www.defenceaviation.com/2010/03/f-35-flightmode.html "F-35B STOVL-mode Flight."] defenceaviation.com. Retrieved 25 November 2010. Jet thrust is sent directly downwards during vertical flight; the nozzle is being redesigned to spread the output across an oval rather than circular shape in order to limit damage to asphalt and ship decks.{{cite web|url=http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/07/19/jsf-heat-woes-being-fixed-trautman/ |title=JSF Heat Woes Being Fixed: Trautman |work=dodbuzz.com |date=19 July 2010 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Colin |last=Clark |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416041003/http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/07/19/jsf-heat-woes-being-fixed-trautman/ |archivedate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The variant's three-bearing swivel nozzle that directs the full thrust of the engine is moved by a [[valve actuator|"fueldraulic" actuator]] using pressurized fuel."Custom tool to save weeks in F-35B test and evaluation." ''Naval Air Systems Command'', 6 May 2011. The United States Marine Corps plans to purchase 340 F-35Bs, to replace current inventories of both the [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18 Hornet]] (A, B, C and D-models), and the AV-8B Harrier II, in the [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] and [[Ground-attack aircraft|attack]] roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marine-corps-aviation-branch-plans-to-invest-in-fighter-jets-helicopters-transports-and-225796/ |title=US Marine Corps aviation branch plans to invest in fighter jets, helicopters, transports and UAVs |work=Flight International |publisher=Reed Business Information |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Trimble |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416041356/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marine-corps-aviation-branch-plans-to-invest-in-fighter-jets-helicopters-transports-and-225796/ |archivedate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Marines plan to use the F-35B from "unimproved surfaces at austere bases" but with "special, high-temperature concrete designed to handle the heat."{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckBlogId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A27103ee8-d867-4e32-a619-92297fa29cf3 |title=About That Austere-Base Thing... |work=aviationweek.com |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Bill |last=Sweetman |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416040527/http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckBlogId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A27103ee8-d867-4e32-a619-92297fa29cf3 |archivedate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}Diamant, Aaron. [http://yuma.usmc.mil/desertwarrior/2011/12/22/feature1.html "JSF construction lands another first."]{{Dead link|date=November 2013}} ''USMC'', 22 December 2011. The USMC declared initial operational capability with about 50 F-35s running interim block 2B software on 31 July 2015.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6613888 "U.S. Military May Deploy F-35 Before Formal IOC."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 24 May 2011. The USAF had considered replacing the [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10]] with the F-35B, but will not do so because of the F-35B's inability to generate enough sorties.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-f-35b-cannot-generate-enough-sorties-to-replace-a-10-371985/ "USAF: F-35B cannot generate enough sorties to replace A-10."] ''Flight Magazine'', 16 May 2012. On 6 January 2011, Gates said that the 2012 budget would call for a two-year pause in F-35B production during which the aircraft faced redesign, or cancellation if unsuccessful.Pew, Glenn. [http://www.avweb.com/avwebflash/news/pentagon_cancel_f35_marine_203914-1.html "Pentagon May Cancel STOVL Version of F-35."] ''AvWeb'', January 2011. In 2011, Lockheed Martin executive vice president Tom Burbage and former Pentagon director of operational testing [[Thomas P. Christie|Tom Christie]] stated that most program delays were due to the F-35B, which forced massive redesigns of other versions.Cox, Bob. "F-35 started with recipe for trouble, analysts say." ''Star Telegram'', 29 January 2011. Lockheed Martin Vice President Steve O’Bryan has said that most F-35B landings will be conventional to reduce stress on vertical lift components.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/06/07/lockheed-many-f-35b-landings-wont-be-vertical/ "Lockheed: Many F-35B landings won’t be vertical."] ''DoD Buzz'', 7 June 2011. These conventional mode takeoffs and landings cause an "unacceptable wear rate" to the aircraft's "poorly designed" tires.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-17/f-35-fighter-s-tires-wear-out-too-soon-pentagon-finds.html|title=F-35 Fighter’s Tires Wear Out Too Soon, Pentagon Finds.|date=17 September 2013|work=Bloomberg|first=Anthony|last=Capaccio}} USMC Lt. Gen. Robert Schmidle has said that the vertical lift components would only be used "a small percentage of the time" to transfer the aircraft from carriers to land bases.{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_07_15_2013_p42-594937.xml |title=Simulations Offer Marines Advanced F-35B Weapons, Training. |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022030447/https://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_07_15_2013_p42-594937.xml |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }} On 3 October 2011, the F-35B began its initial sea-trials by performing a vertical landing on the deck of the amphibious assault ship {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1|6}},Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/the-dewline/2011/10/video-f-35b-completes-first-sh.html "VIDEO: F-35B completes first shipboard vertical landing."] ''The DEWline'', 4 October 2011. to continue in 2015.{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Butler |url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/us-marines-prep-f-35b-ops-trials-uss-wasp |title=U.S. Marines Prep for F-35B Ops Trials on USS Wasp |work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |date=8 April 2015 |accessdate=9 April 2015 }} Probation status was reportedly ended by Defense Secretary Leon Panetta in January 2012 based on progress made. A heat-resistant anti-skid material called Thermion is being tested on Wasp, also useful against the V-22 exhaust.{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Butler |url=http://aviationweek.com/blog/f-35b-dt-2-update-few-hours-uss-wasp |title=F-35B DT 2 Update: A few hours on the USS Wasp |work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |date=5 September 2013 |accessdate=4 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903051254/http://aviationweek.com/blog/f-35b-dt-2-update-few-hours-uss-wasp |archivedate=3 September 2014 |deadurl=no}} Britain's [[Royal Air Force]] and [[Royal Navy]] plan to introduce the F-35B as a replacement for the [[British Aerospace Harrier II|Harrier GR9]], which was retired in 2010, and [[Panavia Tornado|Tornado GR4]], which will retire in 2019. The F-35 is intended to be the United Kingdom's primary strike attack aircraft for the next 3 decades. One of the Royal Navy requirements for the F-35B design was a [[SRVL|Shipborne Rolling and Vertical Landing]] (SRVL) mode to increase maximum landing weight to bring back unused ordnance by using wing lift during landing.[http://www.nao.org.uk/idoc.ashx?docId=c02da1c8-320b-4062-881d-2c24482459b5&version=-1 "Major Projects Report 2008."] ''Ministry of Defence''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120807073545/http://www.nao.org.uk/idoc.ashx?docId=c02da1c8-320b-4062-881d-2c24482459b5&version=-1 |date=7 August 2012 }}[http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2007/06/15/214672/us-marines-eye-uk-jsf-shipborne-technique.html "US Marines eye UK JSF shipborne technique."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Flight International'', 15 June 2007. In July 2013, [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Chief Marshal [[Sir Stephen Dalton]] announced that [[617 Squadron]] would be the first operational Royal Air Force squadron to receive the F-35.{{cite news|title=Royal Air Force's No. 617 Squadron to fly F-35B fighter|url=http://www.airforce-technology.com/news/newsroyal-air-forces-no-617-squadron-to-fly-f-35b-fighter|accessdate=23 July 2013|newspaper=Airforce Technology|date=19 July 2013}}{{cite news|title=Dambusters to be first Lightning II squadron|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/dambusters-to-be-first-lightning-ii-squadron|accessdate=23 July 2013|date=18 July 2013}} The second operational squadron will be the Fleet Air Arm's [[809 Naval Air Squadron|809 NAS]].{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/September/09/130909-809-Air-Squadron|title=Immortal air squadron to fly Royal Navy’s newest jets- Royal Navy|work=mod.uk|accessdate=21 March 2015}} As of June 2013, the [[Royal Air Force]] has received three aircraft of the 48 on order, all of which were based at [[Eglin Air Force Base|Eglin Air Force base]].{{cite web|url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/news/archive/third-joint-strike-fighter-for-the-uk-arrives-28062013|title=Third Joint Strike Fighter for the UK arrives |publisher=RAF |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=2 August 2013}} The F-35 will be based at Royal Air Force Marham and become operational in 2018.{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/equipment/f35jointstrikefighter.cfm |title=F-35B Lightning II |publisher=RAF |date=26 April 2013 |accessdate=30 May 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2013/03/uk-announces-f-35b-basing/ |title=UK announces F-35B basing | Australian Aviation Magazine |work=Australianaviation.com.au |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=31 May 2013}} In June 2015, the F-35B undertook its first launches from a [[Ski-jump ramp|ski-jump]], when one of the UK's aircraft took off using a ramp constructed at [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River|NAS Patuxent River]].{{cite web |url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/news-and-latest-activity/news/2015/june/25/150625-f35-ski-ramp |title=Navy’s new F-35 jump jet flies from trademark ski ramp for first time|publisher=Royal Navy |date=25 June 2015 |accessdate=6 July 2015}} When required to operate from the sea, the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy will operate the F-35B from ships fitted with ski-jumps, as will the Italian [[Italian Navy|Marina Militare]]. In 2011, the Marina Militare was preparing Grottaglie Air Station for F-35B operations; they are to receive 22 aircraft between 2014 and 2021, with the aircraft carrier [[Italian aircraft carrier Cavour (550)|''Cavour'']] set to be modified to operate them by 2016.[http://www.military-today.com/navy/cavour.htm "F-35B on Italian "Cavour" aircraft carrier."] ''Military-today.com'', 4 December 2011. Commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, General [[James Amos]] has said that, in spite of increasing costs and schedule delays, there is no plan B to the F-35B.Kovach, Gretel C. [http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2010/dec/08/commandant-calls-joint-strike-fighter-essential/ "Commandant calls Joint Strike Fighter essential."] ''[[U-T San Diego]]'', 8 December 2010. The F-35B is larger than the aircraft it replaces, which required {{USS|America|LHA-6|6}} to be designed without [[Well dock|well deck]] capabilities.Jean, Grace V. [http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2008/September/Pages/MarinesQuestiontheUtilityof.aspx "Marines Question the Utility of Their New Amphibious Warship."] ''National Defense Industrial Association'', September 2008. In 2011, the USMC and USN signed an agreement by which the USMC will purchase 340 F-35B and 80 F-35C fighters, while the USN will purchase 260 F-35Cs. The five squadrons of USMC F-35Cs will be assigned to Navy carriers; F-35Bs will be used on amphibious ships and ashore. Although the Australian {{sclass|Canberra|landing helicopter dock}} ships were not originally planned to operate fixed-wing aircraft, in May 2014, the [[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Defence]] [[David Johnston (politician)|David Johnston]] stated in media interviews that the government was considering acquiring F-35B fighters for ''Canberra''s, and Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] instructed 2015 Defence White Paper planners to consider the option of embarking F-35B squadrons aboard the two ships.{{cite news|last=Kerr |first=Julian |date=26 May 2014 |url=http://www.janes.com/article/38374/australia-could-buy-f-35b |title=Australia could buy F-35B |work=IHS Jane's Defence Weekly |accessdate=8 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602021021/http://www.janes.com/article/38374/australia-could-buy-f-35b? |archivedate=2 June 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite news |last=Butterly |first=Nick |url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/national/a/23583014/jump-jets-on-defence-radar/ |title=Jump jets on Defence radar |work=The West Australian |publisher=Yahoo7 News |date=17 May 2014 |accessdate=8 June 2014}}{{cite journal|last=Kerr |first=Julian |date=22 December 2011 |title=Amphibious ambitions: expanding Australia's naval expectations |journal=Jane's Navy International |publisher=Jane's Information Group}} Supporters of the idea stated that providing fixed-wing support to amphibious operations would maximize aircraft capability, and the presence of a [[ski-jump ramp]], inherited from the original design, meant that the vessels were better suited to STOVL operations than equivalent ships with flat flight decks.{{cite web |url=http://www.aspistrategist.org.au/lhd-and-stovl-an-engineers-view/ |title=LHD and STOVL: an engineer's view |last=George |first=Steve |date=20 June 2014 |work=The Strategist – The Australian Strategic Policy Institute Blog |publisher=Australian Strategic Policy Institute |accessdate=28 November 2014}} Opponents to the idea countered that embarking enough F-35Bs to be effective required abandoning the ships' amphibious capability and would make the pseudo-carriers more valuable targets, modifications would be required to make the flight deck capable of handling vertical-landing thrust and to increase fuel and ordnance capacity for sustained operations, and that the F-35B project itself has been the most expensive and most problematic of the Joint Strike Fighter variants.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/australian-strategic-policy-institute-raises-doubts-over-abbott-government-plan-to-rebuild-newest-warships/story-fncynjr2-1227128250588 |title=Australian Strategic Policy Institute raises doubts over Abbott Government plan to rebuild newest warships |last=Seidel |first=Jamie |date=19 November 2014 |work=News.com.au |accessdate=28 November 2014}}{{cite journal |last=Brabin-Smith |first=Richard |author2=Schreer, Benjamin |date=17 November 2014 |title=Jump jets for the ADF? |journal=Strategic Insights |publisher=Australian Strategic Policy Institute |issue=78 |url=https://www.aspi.org.au/publications/strategic-insights-78-jump-jets-for-the-adf |accessdate=28 November 2014}}{{cite news |title=Johnston raises possibility of acquiring F-35Bs |url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/05/johnston-raises-possibility-of-acquiring-f-35bs/ |work=Australian Aviation |date=19 May 2014 |accessdate=8 June 2014}} In July 2015 Australia ended consideration of buying the F-35B for its two largest assault ships, as the ship modifications were projected to cost more than AUS$5 billion (US$4.4 billion). The plan was opposed by the Royal Australian Air Force, as an F-35B order could have diminished the number of F-35As purchased.{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/australia-abandons-proposal-order-f-35b|title=Australia Abandons Proposal To Order F35B – Defense content from Aviation Week|work=aviationweek.com|accessdate=31 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/news/politics/pms-floating-fighter-jet-plan-quietly-sunk-by-defence-20150707-gi6qxj|title=PM's floating fighter jet plan quietly sunk by Defence|work=Financial Review|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The U.S Marine Corps plans to disperse its F-35Bs among forward deployed bases to enhance survivability while remaining close to a battlespace, similar to RAF Harrier deployment late in the Cold War which relied on the use of off-base locations that offered short runways, shelter, and concealment. Known as distributed STOVL operations (DSO), Marine F-35Bs would sustain operations from temporary bases in allied territory within the range of hostile ballistic and cruise missiles, but be moved between temporary locations inside the enemy's 24- to 48-hour targeting cycle. This strategy accounts for the F-35B's short range, the shortest of the three variants, with mobile forward arming and refueling points (M-Farps) accommodating [[KC-130]] and [[MV-22 Osprey]] aircraft to rearm and refuel the jets, as well as littoral areas for sea links of mobile distribution sites on land. M-Farps could be based on small airfields, multi-lane roads, or damaged main bases, while F-35Bs would return to U.S. Navy ships, rear-area U.S. Air Force bases, or friendly carriers for scheduled maintenance; metal planking would be needed to protect unprepared roads from the F-35B's engine exhaust, which would be moved between sites by helicopters, and the Marines are studying lighter and more heat-resistant products.[http://aviationweek.com/defense/marines-propose-rapidly-mobile-f-35-operations Marines Propose Rapidly Mobile F-35 Operations] – Aviationweek.com, 16 December 2014 ===F-35C=== [[File:Formation of F-35 Aircraft MOD 45157750.jpg|thumb|F-35s in formation; the greater wing area of the F-35C on left, compared to the F-35B in the middle.]] [[File:F-35C landing on USS Nimitz (CVN-68) in November 2014 (01).JPG|thumb|A F-35C of [[VX-23]] making the first arrested landing aboard {{USS|Nimitz|CVN-68}} on 3 November 2014.]] [[File:F-35C.jpg|thumb|F-35C of VFA-101]] Compared to the F-35A, the F-35C carrier variant features larger wings with [[Folding wing|foldable wingtip sections]], larger wing and tail control surfaces for improved low-speed control, stronger landing gear for the stresses of [[Aircraft carrier|carrier]] arrested landings, a twin-wheel nose gear, and a stronger [[tailhook]] for use with carrier [[arrestor cable]]s. The larger wing area allows for decreased landing speed while increasing both range and payload. The United States Navy intends to buy 480 F-35Cs to replace the F/A-18A, B, C, and D Hornets and complement the Super Hornet fleet.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35c.htm "F-35C Carrier Variant Joint Strike Fighter (JSF)."] ''GlobalSecurity.org.'' Retrieved 16 June 2010. On 27 June 2007, the F-35C completed its Air System Critical Design Review (CDR), allowing the production of the first two functional prototypes.[http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/06-27-2007/0004616904&EDATE= "F-35 Navy Version Undergoes Successful Design Review, Readies for Production."] ''Lockheed Martin'', 7 June 2007. Retrieved 16 June 2010. The C variant was expected to be available beginning in 2014.[[Rebecca L. Grant|Grant, Rebecca L.]], PhD [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/navy-speeds-up-f-35?a=1&c=1171 "Navy Speeds Up F-35."] ''Lexington Institute'', 14 September 2009. Retrieved 20 September 2009. The first F-35C was rolled out on 29 July 2009.[http://frontierindia.net/f-35c-lightning-ii-rolled-out#more-4226 "F-35C Lightning II rolled out."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731151548/http://frontierindia.net/f-35c-lightning-ii-rolled-out#more-4226 |date=31 July 2009 }} FrontierIndia.net, 29 July 2009. The United States Marine Corps will also purchase 80 F-35Cs, enough for five squadrons, for use with navy [[carrier air wing]]s in a joint service agreement signed on 14 March 2011. A recent 2014 document stated that the USMC will also have 4 squadrons of F-35Cs with 10 aircraft per squadron for the Marine Corps' contribution to U.S. Navy [[carrier air wing]]s.{{cite web|url=http://news.usni.org/2014/11/03/document-2015-u-s-marine-corps-aviation-plan|title=Document: 2015 U.S. Marine Corps Aviation Plan|work=USNI News}} On 6 November 2010, the first F-35C arrived at [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River]]. The replacement engines for at-sea repair are too large to be transported by current underway replenishment systems.[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2010/11/navy-jsf-engine-too-big-112910w/ "JSF Engine too big for regular transport at sea."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Navy Times'', 30 November 2010. In 2011, the F-35Cs were grounded for six days after a software bug was found that could have prevented the [[Flight control surfaces|control surfaces]] from being used during flight.Cavas, Christopher P. [http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6915380&c=AIR&s=TOP "U.S. Navy JSFs Resume Flight Ops After Glitch."]{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Defense News'', 24 June 2011. On 27 July 2011, the F-35C test aircraft CF-3 completed its first [[steam catapult]] launch during a test flight at [[Naval Air Engineering Station Lakehurst]]; the TC-13 Mod 2 test steam catapult, representative of current fleet technology, was used. In addition to catapult launches at varying power levels, a three-week test plan included dual-aircraft [[jet blast deflector]] testing and catapult launches using a degraded catapult configuration to measure the effects of steam ingestion on the aircraft.[http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4712 "Catapult launches F-35C for the first time."] ''[[Naval Air Systems Command]]'', 27 July 2011. Retrieved 31 December 2011 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017060039/http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4712 |date=17 October 2014 }} On 13 August 2011, the F-35 successfully completed jet blast deflector (JBD) testing at Lakehurst. F-35C test aircraft CF-1 along with an F/A-18E tested a combined JBD cooling panel configuration. The tests measured temperature, pressure, sound level, velocity, and other environmental data; the JBD model will enable the operation of all carrier aircraft, including the F-35C. Further carrier suitability testing continued in preparation for initial ship trials in 2013.[http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4736 "F-35C completes jet blast deflector testing."] ''[[NAVAIR]]'', 22 August 2011. Retrieved 23 August 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218212655/http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4736 |date=18 December 2014 }} On 18 November 2011, the U.S. Navy used its new [[Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System]] (EMALS) to launch an F-35C into the air for the first time.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/11/28/the-future-is-here-emals-launches-f-35/ "The future is here: EMALS launches F-35."] DODbuzz.com, 28 November 2011. On 22 June 2013, Strike Fighter Squadron [[VFA-101]] received the Navy's first F-35C at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida.{{cite web|url=http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2013/06/us-navy-fleet-squadron-receives-1st-f-35c-jsf/ |title=US Navy Fleet Squadron receives 1st F-35C JSF |work=intercepts.defensenews.com |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=13 March 2014 |first=Christopher P. |last=Cavas |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313220311/http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2013/06/us-navy-fleet-squadron-receives-1st-f-35c-jsf/ |archivedate=13 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite press release|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=74982 |title=Navy Receives First F-35C Lightning II |work=navy.mil |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=13 March 2014 |author=Commander, Naval Air Forces Public Affairs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313220536/http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=74982 |archivedate=13 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The USN is dealing with the following issues in adapting their carriers to operate the F-35C.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-navy-works-through-f-35c-air-ship-integration-issues-377171/ "US Navy works through F-35C air-ship integration issues."] ''Flight International'', 1 October 2012. *The F135 engine exceeds the weight capacity of traditional underway replenishment systems and generates more heat than previous engines. *The stealthy skin requires new repair techniques; extensive skin damage will necessitate repairs at Lockheed's land-based facilities. *The adoption of lithium-ion batteries needing careful thermal management, and higher voltage systems than traditional fighters. *Storing of new weapons not previously employed on carrier aircraft. *Large quantities of classified data generated during missions shall require additional security. In February 2014, Lockheed said the F-35C was on schedule for sea trials after the tailhook was redesigned. The new tailhook has a different shape to better catch arresting wires. Testing on land achieved 36 successful landings. Sea trials were scheduled for October 2014.{{cite news |url=http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304181204579365011426340906 |title=Navy F-35 Set For Sea Trials After Tailhook Redesign: Lockheed Says Naval Version On Schedule |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=5 February 2014 |publisher=[[News Corp]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0099-9660 |oclc=781541372 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |subscription=yes |first=Doug |last=Cameron}} On 3 November 2014, an F-35C of [[VX-23]], one of the Navy's flight test units, made its first landing on an aircraft carrier when it recovered aboard {{USS|Nimitz|CVN-68|6}}; this started a 2 week deployment of a pair of aircraft for the initial at sea Development Testing I or DTI, the first of three at sea tests planned for the F-35C.{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84238 |title=F-35C Completes First Arrested Landing aboard Aircraft Carrier |work=Naval Air Forces, Public Affairs |publisher= US Navy}}{{cite web|url=http://news.usni.org/2014/11/03/u-s-navy-version-f-35-lands-carrier-first-time|title= U.S. Navy Version of F-35 Lands on Carrier for First Time |work=USNI News}} The initial deployment was completed on November 14.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84481|title=F-35C Completes Initial Sea Trials aboard Aircraft Carrier|work=Naval Air Forces, Public Affairs |date=17 November 2014|accessdate=4 December 2014|publisher=US Navy}} The U.S. Navy may use the F-35C as part of its [[UCLASS]] effort to operate a carrier-based [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]. Though it has been suggested that the UCLASS could carry air-to-air weapons, an unmanned aircraft lacks situational awareness and is more vulnerable to electronic countermeasures than manned aircraft, and autonomy for deploying lethal weapons is not under development. With the F-35C as the center of a network of naval systems, it could feed information to the UCLASS and order it to fire on a certain target. Large numbers of F-35Cs operating in contested environments can generate a clear picture of the battlespace, and share it with unmanned assets that can be directed to attack.{{cite web|url=http://thediplomat.com/2014/01/uavs-and-the-f-35-partners-in-air-power/ |title=UAVs and the F-35: Partners in Air Power? |work=thediplomat.com |date=3 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Robert |last=Farley |others=Image Credit: Wikimedia Commons |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525034432/http://thediplomat.com/2014/01/uavs-and-the-f-35-partners-in-air-power/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ===Other versions=== ====F-35I==== {{Main article|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Israeli procurement}} The F-35I ''Adir'' (meaning "awesomeness",{{cite web|website=The Times of Israel|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/jets-name-is-just-plane-awesome/|title=Jet’s name is just plane ‘Awesome’|date=18 April 2013|language=English}} "Mighty One"{{cite web|website=Lockheed Martin|url=https://www.f35.com/news/detail/israels-first-f-35-lightning-ii-takes-flight|title=Israel’s first F-35 Lightning II takes flight|date=26 July 2016}}) is an F-35A with Israeli modifications. A senior [[Israel Air Force]] official stated "the aircraft will be designated F-35I, as there will be unique Israeli features installed in them". Despite an initial refusal to allow such modifications, the U.S. has agreed to let Israel integrate its own electronic warfare systems, such as sensors and countermeasures, into the aircraft. The main computer will have a plug-and-play feature to allow add-on Israeli electronics to be used; proposed systems include an external jamming pod, and new Israeli air-to-air missiles and guided bombs in the internal weapon bays.Ben-David, Alon. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/awst/2010/08/23/AW_08_23_2010_p32-249396.xml "Israel To Buy F-35s With Cockpit Mods."] ''Aviation Week'', 27 August 2010. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}Ben-David, Alon, Amy Butler and Robert Wall. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/awst/2011/07/04/AW_07_04_2011_p22-342412.xml&headline=Israel,%20U.S.%20Strike%20F-35%20Technology%20Deal&prev=10 "Israel, U.S. Strike F-35 Technology Deal."] ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 7 July 2011. Retrieved 8 October 2011. {{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Israeli pilots are scheduled to start F-35 training in December 2016 at Eglin AFB Florida with the first squadron activated about a year later.Harel, Amos. [http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/israel-air-force-crews-to-try-out-next-generation-fighter-jets-by-2016.premium-1.474116 "Israel Air Force crews to try out next-generation fighter jets by 2016."] ''Haaretz Newspaper'', 4 November 2012. [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] (IAI) has considered playing a role in the development of a proposed two-seat F-35; an IAI executive stated: "There is a known demand for two seats not only from Israel but from other air forces."Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/israel-sets-sights-on-two-seater-f-35-337464/ "Israel sets sights on two-seater F-35."] ''Flight International'', 22 January 2010. IAI plans to produce conformal fuel tanks.Egozi, Arie. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/israel-to-boost-range-of-future-f-35-fleet-220748/ "Israel to boost range of future F-35 fleet."] ''Flight International''. 11 January 2008. A senior IAF official stated that elements of the F-35's stealth may be overcome in 5 to 10 years, while the aircraft will be in service for 30 to 40 years, which is why Israel insisted on installing their own electronic warfare systems: "The basic F-35 design is OK. We can make do with adding integrated software."[http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_08_06_2012_p28-482027.xml "Israel, U.S. Agree To $450 Million In F-35 EW Work."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510231649/http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_08_06_2012_p28-482027.xml |date=10 May 2013 }} ''Aviation Week'', 6 August 2012. Israel is interested in purchasing up to 75 F-35s.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/iai-aims-to-complete-f-35-wing-facility-in-mid-2014-389673/ |title=IAI aims to complete F-35 wing facility in mid-2014 |work=flightglobal.com |date=20 August 2013 |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Arie |last=Egozi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525033250/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/iai-aims-to-complete-f-35-wing-facility-in-mid-2014-389673/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ====CF-35==== {{Main article|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Canadian procurement}} The Canadian CF-35 is a proposed variant that would differ from the F-35A through the addition of a [[drogue parachute]] and may include an F-35B/C-style refueling probe.{{cite web |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/news/canada/2010/09/01/15213341.html |title=Harper, Ignatieff spar over fighter jets |work=Calgary Sun |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first=Brian |last=Daly|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.calgarysun.com%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2F2010%2F09%2F01%2F15213341.html&date=2014-03-01|archivedate=2 March 2014|deadurl=no}} In 2012, it was revealed that the CF-35 would employ the same boom refueling system as the F-35A.{{cite web|url=http://o.canada.com/news/national/military-will-contract-out-air-to-air-refuelling-if-canada-goes-with-f-35/ |title=Military will contract out air-to-air refuelling if Canada goes with F-35 |work=o.canada.com |date=20 December 2012 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first=Lee |last=Berthiaume |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302041720/http://o.canada.com/news/national/military-will-contract-out-air-to-air-refuelling-if-canada-goes-with-f-35/ |archivedate=2 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} One alternative proposal would have been the adoption of the F-35C for its probe refueling and lower landing speed; the Parliamentary Budget Officer's report cited the F-35C's limited performance and payload as being too high a price to pay.{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/pbo-dpb/documents/F-35_Cost_Estimate_EN.pdf |title=An Estimate of the Fiscal Impact of Canada’s Proposed Acquisition of the F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first1=Tolga R |last1=Yalkin |first2=Peter |last2=Weltman |publisher=Office of the Parliamentary Budget Office |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302044823/http://www.parl.gc.ca/pbo-dpb/documents/F-35_Cost_Estimate_EN.pdf |archivedate=2 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Following the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 Federal Election]], in which the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]], whose campaign had included a pledge to cancel the F-35 procurement,{{cite web|url = https://www.liberal.ca/files/2015/10/New-plan-for-a-strong-middle-class.pdf|title = A New Plan For a Strong Middle Class|accessdate = 5 October 2015|author = [[Liberal Party of Canada]]|date = 5 October 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151014055323/https://www.liberal.ca/files/2015/10/New-plan-for-a-strong-middle-class.pdf |archivedate=14 October 2015 }} won a majority in the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]], and stated it would run a new competition for an aircraft to replace the existing [[McDonnell Douglas CF-18 Hornet|CF-18 Hornet]].{{cite web |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/canadian-f-35-exit-could-signal-wider-air-force-revi-418043/ |title=Canadian F-35 exit could signal wider air force review |last1=Drew |first1=James |last2= |first2= |date=21 October 2015 |website=Flight Global |publisher= |access-date=6 November 2015 |quote=}} ====F-35D==== Early-stage design study for a possible upgrade of the F-35A to be fielded by the 2035 target date of the Air Force Future Operating Concept.{{cite news ===F-35C=== ;{{USA}} *[[United States Marine Corps]] – 80 planned **[[VFA-101]] – [[Eglin AFB]], [[Florida]] (Navy squadron, but trains both Navy and Marine F-35C pilots, and operates Navy and Marine F-35Cs maintained by both Sailors and Marines. This is the same arrangement as other aircraft common to the Navy and Marine Corps.) *[[United States Navy]] – 260 planned **[[VX-23]] – [[NAS Patuxent River]], [[Maryland]]{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84238 |title=F-35C Completes First Arrested Landing aboard Aircraft Carrier |work=Naval Air Forces, Public Affairs |publisher= US Navy |accessdate=4 February 2015}} **[[VFA-101]] – [[Eglin AFB]], [[Florida]]{{cite web|url=http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/navys-vfa-101-stands-up-at-eglin/|title=Navy's VFA-101 Stands Up at Eglin – Defense Media Network|work=Defense Media Network|accessdate=4 February 2015}} ==Accidents== On 23 June 2014, an F-35A preparing to take off on a training flight at Eglin Air Force Base experienced a fire in the engine area. The pilot escaped unharmed. The accident caused all training to be halted on 25 June, and all flights halted on 3 July. During the incident investigation, engine parts from the burned aircraft were discovered on the runway, indicating it was a substantial engine failure.{{cite news|last1=Shalal|first1=Andrea|title=Engine pieces found on runway after F-35 fire – sources|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/27/lockheed-fighter-engine-idUSL2N0P818G20140627|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=Reuters.Com|agency=Reuters|issue=US Edition|publisher=Thomson Reuters|date=27 June 2014}} The fleet was returned to flight on 15 July with restrictions in the flight envelope. Preliminary findings suggests that excessive rubbing of the engine fan blades created increased stress and wear and eventually resulted in catastrophic failure of the fan.{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140713/SHOWSCOUT15/307130026/Kendall-Fan-Blade-Rubbing-Cause-F-35-Fire|title=Kendall: Fan-Blade Rubbing Cause of F-35 Fire|work=Defense News|accessdate=21 September 2014}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} In early June 2015, the USAF Air Education and Training Command (AETC) issued its official report on the incident. It found that the incident was the result of a failure of the third stage rotor of the engine's fan module. The report explained that "pieces of the failed rotor arm cut through the engine's fan case, the engine bay, an internal fuel tank, and hydraulic and fuel lines before exiting through the aircraft's upper fuselage". Pratt and Whitney, the engine manufacturers, developed two remedies to the problem. The first is an extended "rub-in" to increase the gap between the second stator and the third rotor integral arm seal. The second is the redesign to pre-trench the stator. Both should be complete by early 2016. Cost of the problem was estimated at USD 50 million. All aircraft resumed operations within 25 days of the incident.{{cite journal|last1=Malenic|first1=Marina|title=Pentagon releases report on F-35 engine failure|journal=IHS Janes Defence Weekly|date=17 June 2015|volume=52|issue=24|page=13|accessdate=2 July 2015}} ==Specifications (F-35A)== [[File:F-35A three-view.PNG|thumb]] [[File:F-35 in hangar.jpg|thumb|The first of 15 pre-production F-35s]] [[File:F-35B cutaway with LiftFan.jpg|thumb|F-35B cutaway with LiftFan]] {{aircraft specifications |jet or prop?=jet |plane or copter?=plane |ref=Lockheed Martin specifications,[https://web.archive.org/web/20110317114148/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/f35/f-35b-stovl-variant.html "F-35B Short Takeoff/Vertical Landing Variant."] ''Lockheed Martin''.
